discussion: Assess functioning by asking each partner for relationship history; Questions could include: 'How did the two of you meet?' 'What attracted you to each other?' 'What qualities or characteristics did you find that you liked about your partner?' 'How did the two of you decide to get married?' 'How was the adjustment after you got married?' 'What have been the highs and lows during dating and your marriage?'

sessions.short_term_objective: Create jealousy timeline for current relationship.
discussion: Beginning with their first meeting, draw a timeline and have partners rate the level of jealousy between 0 (no jealousy) and 100 (most jealousy ever experienced); ask partners to elaborate on the events/contexts that are related to major increases and decreases in jealousy from their first meeting until the present.

sessions.short_term_objective: Complete the 'Catch Your Partner Pleasing You' exercise at home and bring the list to the next session.
discussion: Increase caring behaviors and counter negative selective attention by assigning clients the 'Catch Your Partner Pleasing You' exercise (i.e., client records at least one positive behavior each day by partner, and at least one by self).

sessions.short_term_objective: Identify and list behavioral changes for self and partner that would enhance the relationship.
discussion: Assign each partner to list changes for self and the other that would improve the relationship (e.g., modified instructions for the 'Areas of Change' questionnaire by Weiss & Birchler or assign 'Positive and Negative Contributions to the Relationship: Mine and Yours' in the Adult Psychotherapy Homework Planner, 2nd ed. by Jongsma); review and discuss the lists in session.

Assign each partner to analyze the list of behaviors to be performed by self and the partner that would benefit the relationship; prioritize the list from least to greatest in terms of the effort, trust, and sacrifice each behavior would require (e.g., using 'Cost/Benefit Analysis' by Weiss). Assign mutual enactment of the behaviors, requiring the least amount of trust and commitment first, following later with those of greater cost.

sessions.short_term_objective: List relationship issues that contribute to dissatisfaction and unhappiness and agree to address these in future conjoint sessions.
discussion: Devise and enact a treatment plan for addressing specific couple problems (such as communication issues or sexual dissatisfaction) by reviewing pertinent sections of this Planner, negotiating plan with clients, and executing appropriate interventions.

sessions.short_term_objective: Jealous partner list behaviors that can be changed by other partner to minimize jealousy.
discussion: Have jealous partner list and prioritize what he/she would like the other partner to do to minimize own feelings of jealousy.

sessions.short_term_objective: Discuss requests made by the jealous partner and come to an agreement about the behavioral changes that seem reasonable to help minimize jealousy.
discussion: Encourage the jealous partner to reconsider some requests for change he/she has made regarding partner that may be self-defeating or overly demanding.
Encourage the partners to jointly conclude which behaviors would be reasonable for reaching a goal of minimizing jealousy.

sessions.short_term_objective: Using problem-solving techniques, negotiate rules regarding each partner’s interaction with others in social situations.
discussion: Using problem-solving techniques (e.g., define the problem specifically, generate at least two solutions, weigh the pros/cons of each solution before choosing one solution, enact a solution, evaluate the results, modify the solution if necessary); negotiate rules about how partners should behave when around other people, the degree of individual freedom each should have, and behaviors that are explicitly permitted and explicitly prohibited.

long_term_goals: Increase positive coping behaviors to reduce negative effects of work stress.
Increase positive attitudes about job and/or job alternatives.
Begin the process of searching for new and more desirable employment.
Obtain further training and/or retraining in work-related skills.
Reduce depressed mood and sleep disturbance while increasing energy level.
Reduce anger and terminate explosive outbursts at work and at home.

sessions.short_term_objective: Identify sources of irritability, depressed mood, and related depressive symptoms.
discussion: Assist the stressed partner in listing all the work-related factors that make him/her depressed, angry, or discouraged.
Have the stressed partner rank in order the employment factors that are most significant in causing his/her depression.

Develop a plan with the stressed partner to address coping (e.g., increased recreational diversions, relaxation and deep-breathing techniques, physical exercise, assertiveness training, job transfer) with the most important work-related stressors.
Have the stressed partner rank in order the perceived causes (and associated factors) of depression.

sessions.short_term_objective: Identify sources of anger.
discussion: Have the stressed partner list all of the job-related factors that make him/her angry.
Ask the stressed partner to rank in order the most important job-related factors that make him/her angry.
Develop a plan to resolve (e.g., increased communication, assertiveness training, problem pinpointing/resolution training) causes for anger.
Have the other partner rank in order the perceived causes (and associated factors) of anger in the job-stressed partner.

sessions.short_term_objective: Explore whether some other mental health problem is the primary cause for unhappiness.
discussion: Explore with the partners whether some other individual problem (e.g., chronic depression, alcohol abuse, or sleep disorder) may be the primary cause for unhappiness.

sessions.short_term_objective: Use antidepressant or anti-anxiety medication as prescribed by physician.
discussion: Refer the stressed partner to a physician for medication, and encourage him/her to take medication regularly.

sessions.short_term_objective: Consider a medical leave of absence from work responsibilities.
discussion: Explore with the stressed partner the advantages and disadvantages of taking medical leave.
Obtain input from the other partner about the advantages and disadvantages of medical leave.

sessions.short_term_objective: Assess and articulate own ability to handle technical requirements of job.
discussion: Ask the stressed partner to obtain feedback about job performance from supervisor and peers, if doing so is practical.
Have the partner assess his/her ability to perform the technical aspects of the job.

sessions.short_term_objective: Enlist support of partner to help cope with job stress.
discussion: Have the other partner advise the stressed partner on how he/she can best support him/her during the next few months to assist in coping with job stress.
Explore whether the partner can help the stressed partner’s situation by providing more financial support.

sessions.short_term_objective: Contact agencies that provide instruction and training in areas relevant to current job.
discussion: Refer the stressed partner to an agency that could provide assessment and/or job-skill training.
Refer the stressed partner to an educational institution with curriculum that could enhance job skills and/or enable the partner to obtain new degree or certificate.

sessions.short_term_objective: Commit to further instruction and/or training to enhance job skills.
discussion: Have the stressed partner verbally commit to further training or education.

sessions.short_term_objective: Attend classes to obtain further education and vocational training or obtain information on computer-assisted home-teaching packages that would enhance job skills.
discussion: Support and reinforce the stressed partner in efforts to pursue further training through an educational institution or via computer-assisted home instruction.
Explore with the stressed partner possible alternative jobs that would be available upon completion of a course of study.

sessions.short_term_objective: Make positive statements to self and others about the future.
discussion: Assign the stressed partner to make one positive statement to someone at work each day about the work and/or work environment.
Assign the other partner to tell the stressed partner something positive about work each day.
Assign the other partner to support the stressed partner’s affirming of positive aspects of work and to add own positive perspective on the stressed partner’s work.

Explore the stressed partner’s cognitions for self-defeating messages that lead to feelings of hopelessness and helplessness; assist the partner in replacing these negative thoughts with more realistic, energizing thoughts that lead to constructive actions (or assign “A Vocational Action Plan” in the Adult Psychotherapy Homework Planner, 2nd ed. by Jongsma).

sessions.short_term_objective: Decrease critical and complaining comments at work and at home.
discussion: Advise the stressed partner to avoid making negative comments about work to colleagues.
Assign the other partner to provide support and reinforcement for the stressed partner’s decreasing negative comments about work.
Have the stressed partner and the other partner list advantages of reducing complaining and critical comments about the work situation.

sessions.short_term_objective: Make some acceptable changes in work space to enhance physical and emotional aspects of working environment.
discussion: Explore with the partner possible acceptable ways of making his/her work space or office more pleasant and attractive.
Encourage the partner to take something attractive to work to decorate his/her office (e.g. picture, poster, clock).
Encourage the partner to clean his/her office and arrange things neatly.

sessions.short_term_objective: Limit time on work activities to allow for family time.
discussion: Assist the partners in reviewing their weekly schedules in order to set aside recurring family time.
Ask the partners to agree to say “no” gracefully when family priorities are threatened.

sessions.short_term_objective: Read sources regarding family and work balance.
discussion: Read the following: Work-Life Balance for Dummies by Mumford & Lockette, The One Minute Manager Balances Work and Life by Blanchard, Edington, & Blanchard, or First Things First by Covey, Merrill, & Merrill.

long_term_goals: Resolve negative feelings and relationship conflict generated by the life-changing event, making adaptive responses to the situation that foster individual and relationship growth.
Adapt to the life-changing event by using personal, relationship, and social resources.
Recognize the difference between transition problems that can be changed and those that cannot.
Strengthen the relationship by being accepting of, and supportive of, each other.
As a couple, seek social supports to help buffer negative effects of the transition.

sessions.short_term_objective: Describe the life-changing event and its impact on each partner and the relationship.
discussion: Have each partner define the life-changing event and its meaning to him/her individually and to the relationship.
Determine whether the event was expected or unexpected.

sessions.short_term_objective: Verbalize acceptance of the fact that change is inevitable in everyone’s life.
discussion: Normalize the process of change in everyone’s life by reviewing common changes that occur in the various developmental stages of life.

sessions.short_term_objective: Each partner identifies the stage of change in adapting to current life-changing event.
discussion: Administer “Stages of Change” questionnaire (Prochaska et al., 1994) to determine which of the four stages of change (pre-contemplation, contemplation, action, or maintenance) best describes each partner’s current adaptation to the transition; review and discuss the results with partners.

sessions.short_term_objective: List ways of coping with the change that have been positive and productive.
discussion: Ask each partner to describe his/her ways of coping with the current stressor that are productive.

sessions.short_term_objective: List ways of coping with the change that have been negative and counterproductive.
discussion: Ask each partner to describe his/her ways of coping with the current stressor that are counterproductive.

sessions.short_term_objective: Identify the positive and negative aspects of the life change.
discussion: Have partners discuss the positive and negative aspects of the life-changing event.

sessions.short_term_objective: Describe the anxiety and stress that the life-changing event has produced.
discussion: Teach that anxiety and strain are normal responses when coping with both good and bad life-changing events (e.g., the birth of a child, diagnosis of an illness, a job layoff).

sessions.short_term_objective: Identify the pros and cons of the life-changing event for self individually.
discussion: Ask one partner to describe how the life-changing event may have positive effects for him/her individually, and have the other partner respond using supportive listener skills (i.e., paraphrasing, reflecting).

Ask one partner to describe how the life-changing event may have negative effects for him/her individually, and have the other partner respond using supportive listener skills (i.e., paraphrasing, reflecting).

sessions.short_term_objective: Identify the pros and cons of the life-changing event for the relationship.
discussion: Ask each partner to describe how the life-changing event may have positive effects on the relationship.
Ask each partner to describe how the life-changing event may have negative effects on the relationship.

sessions.short_term_objective: Describe the day-to-day changes that the life-changing event will precipitate.
discussion: Help the partners identify the concrete, day-to-day changes that the life-changing event will require.

sessions.short_term_objective: Identify goals for short-term changes to be made in adapting to the current situation.
discussion: Help each partner identify changes that will have to be made by self in the short term.

sessions.short_term_objective: Identify goals for long-term changes to be made in adapting to the current situation.
discussion: Help each partner identify changes that have to be made by self for the long term.

sessions.short_term_objective: Increase use of empathic listening skills in response to the other partner, stating what behaviors the partner could increase and those he/she could decrease in order to be supportive.
discussion: Have each partner describe what supportive behaviors he/she could increase during the transition, and have other partner respond using supportive listener skills.
Have each partner describe what negative behaviors he/she could decrease during the transition, and have other partner respond using supportive listener skills.

sessions.short_term_objective: Identify support systems outside of the relationship that are currently available or can be added to assist in coping with the change.
discussion: Explore the support systems already in place outside of the relationship that can aid both partners in coping (e.g., friends, self-help and support groups, religious organizations).

sessions.short_term_objective: Increase the use of individualized stress-reducing activities.
discussion: Teach personal relaxation techniques (e.g., diaphragmatic breathing, progressive relaxation) that can be used as coping mechanisms, to deal with the stress of life-changing events.
Encourage each partner to commit to regular individual stress-reducing activities (e.g., relaxation techniques, exercise, music, hobbies).

sessions.short_term_objective: Increase the use of shared stress-reducing activities.
discussion: Encourage both partners to commit to regular couple stress-reducing activities (e.g., foot rubs, social engagements, walks, sex, shared hobbies).

sessions.short_term_objective: Identify those problems that can be controlled, and those that must be accepted and adapted to.
discussion: Help the partners identify which problems are within their control and which problems to which they need to adapt.

sessions.short_term_objective: Pinpoint the changes that will be required in the personal, relational, and social domains.
discussion: To set stage for solving problems within partners’ control, have them pinpoint adaptations required in the personal, relational, and social domains.

sessions.short_term_objective: Using brainstorming techniques develop at least two solutions to each change that is required.
discussion: Teach partners to brainstorm at least two solutions for each problem before trying to solve the problem, and have them practice this in session.
Teach partners to evaluate the pros and cons of the brainstormed solutions, and have them practice this in session.

sessions.short_term_objective: Agree to a specific plan for enacting the selected solutions.
discussion: Teach partners to make a specific, pinpointed plan for each solution, including a time in the future to evaluate the progress on the solution; have them practice this in session.

sessions.short_term_objective: Validate and empathize with other partner’s feelings regarding the difficulty of accepting a problem that cannot be changed or controlled.
discussion: For problems outside partners’ control, role-play support and acceptance by having one person “vent” about difficult aspects of coping with the transition and ask the listener to practice validation skills (i.e., conveying that he/she understands and can empathize with the speaker’s feelings, even if he/she does not agree).

When dealing with problems outside the partners’ control instruct them to avoid trying to solve the external problem, but instead support each other and problem-solve how they can accept the unchangeable problem.
If understanding or problem-solving is at an impasse, have partners switch places and then discuss the issue from the other’s perspective.

sessions.short_term_objective: Describe what in six months could be the best possible outcome to the life-changing event.
discussion: Ask the partners to envision themselves six months from now and to describe their functional adaptation to the transition.

sessions.short_term_objective: Increase the frequency of mutually enjoyable activities with partner to promote relationship support and harmony.
discussion: Assist the partners in identifying pleasant activities each would enjoy engaging in together; assign the partners to schedule regular positive activities with each other during the stressful transition period (or assign each partner to complete and then share the homework exercise “Identify and Schedule Pleasant Activities” in the Adult Psychotherapy Homework Planner, 2nd ed. by Jongsma).

long_term_goals: Overcome reasons for lack of caring and increase verbal, behavioral, and physical expressions of kindness, affection, and sexual intimacy.
Increase communication about all issues.
Increase acts of kindness and thoughtfulness with partner.
Increase time spent together in social and recreational activities.
Increase overall feelings and expressions of love and caring between the partners.
Increase amount of physical intimacy and satisfying sexual interaction with partner.

sessions.short_term_objective: Identify reasons for lack of caring by partner.
discussion: Have each partner list the reasons that caring has eroded in the relationship (or assign 'Positive and Negative Contributions to the Relationship: Mine and Yours' in the Adult Psychotherapy Homework Planner, 2nd ed. by Jongsma).
Review with the partners the reasons for the erosion of caring.
Address the possible need for individual therapy to help the partners cope with any individual problems that interfere with the development of caring in the relationship.

sessions.short_term_objective: Begin to make restitution to partner for past wrongs.
discussion: Obtain a commitment from both partners to make restitution for respective wrongs and transgressions in the relationship.
If one partner’s actions have caused the other to experience jealousy, obtain a commitment from that partner to work especially hard at reassuring the other of his/her commitment to the relationship.
Have the partners provide feedback to each other about specific actions that will help build mutual trust.

sessions.short_term_objective: Verbalize an understanding of forgiveness as a process, not a one-time event.
discussion: Ask the partners to share their definitions of and thoughts about forgiveness.

Provide a copy of Baucom, Snyder, & Gordon’s (2009, p. 285) handout listing what forgiveness is ('a process; a release from being dominated by negative thoughts, feelings, and behaviors; a chance to learn about and gain more understanding of your partner, your relationship, and yourself') and what forgiveness is not ('forgetting; reconciliation; an immediate event; a one-time event').
Ask the partners to discuss their fears or apprehensions about forgiveness.
Ask the partners to discuss (a) the repercussions of not forgiving and (b) the potential payoffs of forgiving.
Challenge maladaptive beliefs about forgiveness (e.g., forgiveness implies weakness, condones the affair, excuses the affair, etc.).

sessions.short_term_objective: Read books on the process of forgiving another person.
discussion: Recommend that the partners read a book on forgiveness (e.g., Forgive and Forget: Healing the Hurts We Don’t Deserve by Smedes or Forgiveness Is a Choice: A Step-by-Step Process for Resolving Anger and Restoring Hope by Enright).

sessions.short_term_objective: Commit to moving forward and to letting go of past issues.
discussion: Obtain a verbal commitment between the partners and the therapist to attempt to move forward and to put past issues behind them, at least for a specified period.

sessions.short_term_objective: Increase eye contact with the partner.
discussion: Teach the partners to maintain eye contact with each other while speaking and listening.
Provide feedback to the partners about the extent to which each maintains eye contact with the other.

sessions.short_term_objective: Decrease critical comments toward the other partner.
discussion: Educate the partners regarding the very negative impact of making critical and hostile comments to each other in therapy sessions or at home.

Obtain a commitment from the partners to minimize critical and hostile comments toward each other (or assign 'Alternatives to Destructive Anger' in the Adult Psychotherapy Homework Planner, 2nd ed. by Jongsma).

Advise the partners that individual therapy may be needed as an adjunct or precursor to conjoint therapy, especially if expressions of anger by one or both partners in conjoint sessions cannot be contained.

sessions.short_term_objective: Increase positive verbal communication with the other partner.
discussion: Assist each partner in identifying the types of positive feedback that are pleasing to the other partner (e.g., some partners care about feedback about attire, while others regard such comments as irrelevant).
Using behavior-rehearsal techniques, have the partners make positive comments about each other and about each other’s positive behaviors.
Reinforce attempts by clients to be verbally supportive of each other.

sessions.short_term_objective: Increase acts of kindness and helpfulness toward the other partner (e.g., complete a task for the partner, run an errand for the partner).
discussion: Assist each partner in identifying the types of kind or helpful behaviors that are pleasing to the other partner (e.g., some partners care about getting the house cleaned, while others do not care much about that).

Obtain an agreement from the partners regarding specific helpful, thoughtful gestures each will perform during the week (or assign 'How Can We Meet Each Other’s Needs and Desires?' in the Adult Psychotherapy Homework Planner, 2nd ed. by Jongsma).
Reinforce attempts by the partners to engage in nonverbal and nonphysical affectionate gestures, such as doing a chore with or for the partner.

sessions.short_term_objective: Increase expressions of praise, compliments, recognition, and gratitude to the other partner.
discussion: Prompt mutual expressions of praise, compliments, recognition, and gratitude by the partners during and between therapy sessions; assign the partners to log the giving and receiving of such comments as a means of reinforcing the process.
Monitor the partners’ progress in mutually reinforcing each other and provide support for this effort.

sessions.short_term_objective: Identify activities that self and the partner would enjoy together.
discussion: Have the partners describe social and recreational activities that they might like to do together.

sessions.short_term_objective: Engage in pleasurable social and recreational activities with the partner.
discussion: Facilitate an agreement between the partners regarding a specific plan for some social or recreational activities together, even if they feel somewhat reluctant to do so initially.
Obtain feedback about how each partner felt during the mutual activity, and assist in helping expand such activities where possible.

sessions.short_term_objective: Acknowledge that in unsatisfactory relationships changes in feelings generally follow changes in behavior.
discussion: Educate the partners about the usual course of change, emphasizing that initial changes in behaviors generally lead to subsequent changes in feelings and attitudes.

sessions.short_term_objective: Verbalize realistic, attainable time goals for expression of feelings of affection, and intimacy.
discussion: Educate the partners regarding the need for patience when seeking changes in positive relationship feelings.
Assist the partners in setting realistic goals about changes in caring and love.

sessions.short_term_objective: Express commitment to not verbally coerce partner into sexual activities; acknowledge that sexual activities should be mutually agreed upon.
discussion: Advise the partners that forced sexual activities often backfire, with coercion by one partner frequently leading to resentment and withdrawal by the other.

Obtain a commitment from both the partners (and especially from the partner who has been the most frequent initiator of sexual activity) to only initiate and engage in sexual actions that are mutually agreed upon.

sessions.short_term_objective: Verbalize an understanding that positive sexual interchanges generally follow when other aspects of the relationship improve.
discussion: Explain to the partners that sexual satisfaction in marital and long-term relationships often increases naturally even without direct attention to the sexual relationship (unless there are specific sexual dysfunctions) when other aspects of the relationship, such as communication and nonsexual expressions of caring, improve.

sessions.short_term_objective: Implement the techniques of sensate focus to increase the giving and receiving of physical pleasure.
discussion: If both partners are willing, teach them the techniques of sensate focus, where each partner alternates between giving and receiving sensual pleasure (or assign 'Journaling the Response to Non-demand, Sexual Pleasuring [Sensate Focus]' in the Adult Psychotherapy Homework Planner, 2nd ed. by Jongsma).
Monitor, review, and discuss the partners’ feelings surrounding their increase in physically intimate contact.

sessions.short_term_objective: Read educational material regarding human sexuality and techniques of pleasuring.
discussion: Assign the partners to read, either independently or together material on sexual relationships (e.g., Sexual Awareness by McCarthy & McCarthy, Rekindling Desire by McCarthy & McCarthy, or The Gift of Sex by Penner & Penner).

long_term_goals: Reduce symptoms of depression and anxiety related to ambiguity of direction and values in life.
Resolve the conflict that precipitated the midlife crises.
Increase focus on living in accordance with specified goals and clarified values.
Recognize advantages that usually come only with maturity.
Become connected or reconnected to partner, family members, employment, and/or religious community.
Rediscover an appreciation for and commitment to the existing intimate relationship.

sessions.short_term_objective: Describe the mismatch between life goals and accomplishments that seem to trigger midlife transition difficulties.
discussion: Ask the client experiencing midlife transition difficulties to describe the mismatch between life goals and accomplishments.

sessions.short_term_objective: Cooperate with an assessment of midlife transition difficulties by completing the Midlife Crisis Scale.
discussion: Ask the client experiencing midlife transition difficulties to complete the Midlife Crisis Scale (Hermans & Oles); provide feedback to the client as to test results.

sessions.short_term_objective: Verbalize the thoughts that are associated with anxiety and worry over the future.
discussion: Probe for the client’s cognitive distortions that lead to anxiety and uneasiness.
Assign the client homework to track events/thoughts that precipitate anxious and depressed feelings (for use in situational analyses).

sessions.short_term_objective: Organize a list of thoughts, behaviors, actual outcomes, and desired outcomes via situational analysis of midlife transition-problem experiences.
discussion: Demonstrate how to organize a situational analysis. Have the client choose from his/her homework specific midlife problem-eliciting situations and tell what his/her interpretations/cognitions were, what his/her behavior was, and what the actual outcome of the situation was.
As the concluding step in the situational analysis, have the client describe what his/her desired outcome was in the specified situation.

sessions.short_term_objective: Verbalize thoughts that were unhelpful, global, or inaccurate, and then state more beneficial self-talk.
discussion: Help the client determine whether each thought was (a) accurate, (b) anchored to the specific situation, and (c) helpful in getting the desired outcome.

If any thoughts are not accurate, anchored, and helpful in getting the desired outcome, have the client rework the thoughts so they meet criteria (for example, 'I only get to have sex with one woman for the rest of my life' can become 'I’m fortunate to have sex regularly with someone who loves and respects me').

sessions.short_term_objective: Articulate the values and goals for living a meaningful life using Covey’s four human needs and the approach taken to fulfill those needs.
discussion: Ask the partners to read First Things First (Covey, Merrill, & Merrill), which posits that cross-cultural wisdom literature contains four key human needs 'to live, to love, to learn, to leave a legacy.'

Ask the partners to consider their approach to fulfilling the need 'to live' ('Our physical need for such things as food, clothing, economic well-being, health,' Covey et al., p. 45) by having them write and discuss (a) their past and current goals for meeting financial needs, and (b) the pros and cons of their current approach.

Ask the partners to consider their approach to fulfilling the need 'to love' ('Our social need to relate to other people, to belong, to love, to be loved,' Covey et al., p. 45) by having them write and discuss (a) their past and current goals for having rich, satisfying relationships with others, and (b) the pros and cons of their current approach.

Ask the partners to consider their approach to fulfilling the need 'to learn' ('Our mental need to develop and to grow,' Covey et al., p. 45) by having them write and discuss (a) their past and current goals for learning, growing, and being open to new experiences and skills, and (b) the pros and cons of their current approach.

Ask the partners to consider their approach to fulfilling the need 'to leave a legacy' ('Our spiritual need to have a sense of meaning, purpose, personal congruence, and contribution,' Covey et al., p. 45) by having them write and discuss (a) their past and current goals for having a sense of direction and purpose, and (b) the pros and cons of their current approach.

sessions.short_term_objective: Identify developmental history of goals held for self and perceived expectations of others for self.
discussion: Have each partner describe his/her goals and wishes as a late teen and young adult in the areas of (a) to live, (b) to love, (c) to learn, and (d) to leave a legacy; how have these changed over the years?
Have each partner describe the goals and wishes his/her parents had for him/her.
Have each partner describe perceived goals that the other partner had for him/her.

sessions.short_term_objective: Each partner describes goals he/she has had for the other partner.
discussion: Obtain feedback from each partner regarding goals and wishes he/she has for the other.

sessions.short_term_objective: Describe goals that have remained unfulfilled and the feelings associated with that lack of fulfillment.
discussion: Have each partner describe his/her unfulfilled goals; assist each partner in identifying the feelings associated with failure to attain those goals.

sessions.short_term_objective: Verbalize acceptance that some goals cannot be attained.
discussion: Assist the client in identifying goals that probably are not realistically attainable and that must be accepted as such; review and discuss the client’s feelings associated with this reality.

sessions.short_term_objective: List realistic, meaningful alternative goals for future attainment and steps needed to reach them.
discussion: Have the client list goals that are still realistically attainable and plans he/she has to reach them; clarify why these goals are meaningful and of value to self, partner, and the relationship.
Assign the client to consult other individuals whom he/she respects regarding possible alternative goals for himself/herself and their value.
Obtain feedback from each partner about the perceived value of alternative goals to self and to the relationship.
Assist the client in determining the likelihood of attaining alternative goals; ask the client to lay out steps necessary to attain these new goals.

sessions.short_term_objective: Each partner constructs a self-change plan to accomplish an articulated goal.
discussion: Teach the partners the five steps of a Self-Change Plan (1) Describe the behavior to be changed; (2) Examine the pros and cons of the current behavior; (3) Set a goal, describing as precisely as possible what is to happen; (4) Create an Action Plan, pinpointing a specific plan for enacting the goal; and (5) Evaluate enacting of the plan. Have the partners practice this in session on an articulated goal that each would like to achieve.

Ask the partners to make a global evaluation of how they did on implementing the action plan before the next session. The rating scale is 0 = didn’t think about it or do it; 1 = thought about it; 2 = gave it a weak try; 3 = tried, partially succeeded; and 4 = did a great job. Ask them to jot down short answers to the following: What did we actually do? What positives resulted? What negatives resulted? What do we need to do from here?

sessions.short_term_objective: Identify the advantages that come with maturity.
discussion: Have partners describe attributes of an older individual whom he/she respects.

Help the partners identify advantages that usually come with maturity (e.g., less impulsive judgments, greater experiential wisdom, broader views of values in life, knowledge of more lifestyle alternatives, more concern about others).

sessions.short_term_objective: Verbalize acceptance of own aging and sense of peace over it.
discussion: Help the partners identify advantages that usually come with maturity (e.g., less impulsive judgments, greater experiential wisdom, broader views of values in life, knowledge of more lifestyle alternatives, and more concern about others).
Explore and resolve the client’s possible feelings of anxiety and fatalistic depression related to aging, including fear of physical deterioration and/or declining health.

sessions.short_term_objective: Identify steps that could be taken to increase current or future financial security.
discussion: Ask the partners to create and enact self-change plans related to financial security.

sessions.short_term_objective: Clarify and articulate the beneficial value of giving more time to family relationships.
discussion: Assist the partners in identifying the benefits of increased contact with immediate and extended family members and to create and enact self-change plans related to loving relationships.

sessions.short_term_objective: Identify acts of kindness that could be done for others, and articulate benefits of self-sacrifice and focusing on others.
discussion: Assist the partners in identifying things that they might do (alone or together) for others, thereby reducing the focus on themselves; ask them to create and enact self-change plans related to helping others.

sessions.short_term_objective: Verbalize an understanding of the value of touching in intimate human relationships.
discussion: Teach the partners the value of touching in intimate relationships (i.e., increases partners’ feelings of importance; enhances mutual feelings of closeness, warmth, caring, and security).

sessions.short_term_objective: Increase level of physical affection with partner.
discussion: Ask the partners to create and enact self-change plans related to solidifying, improving, and/or increasing physical affection.

sessions.short_term_objective: Increase new and interesting experiences/skills.
discussion: Explore what new experiences and skills might interest the partners; ask them to create and enact self-change plans related to trying new experiences (alone or together) and to learning new skills.

sessions.short_term_objective: Increase behaviors that provide a sense of leaving a legacy.
discussion: Ask the partners to consider what they would like others to say (a) about their relationship at a 50th anniversary party, and (b) about them at a 70th birthday party. Assist them in deriving lessons about the legacies they would like to leave and the behavior changes necessary to achieve that legacy.
Ask the partners to create and enact self-change plans related to behavioral involvements that give them a sense of meaning, purpose, personal congruence, and contribution.

sessions.short_term_objective: Articulate feelings and thoughts associated with their current employment and the vision for a future in this work or a possible alternative employment situation.
discussion: Explore the partners’ feelings associated with current employment and what impact it has on each partner and the family.
Assist the partners in identifying possible alternative career directions and the advantages and disadvantages of each possibility for selves and the relationship.

sessions.short_term_objective: Verbalize a commitment to accept current employment situation.
discussion: Help the partners accept and commit to present employment with a sense of satisfaction and without resentment or negative self-talk regarding lack of accomplishment or future advancement.

sessions.short_term_objective: State a concrete plan for exploring other career opportunities that have been identified as challenging and appropriate.
discussion: Assist the partners in developing a plan for responsibly exploring alternative career directions while avoiding impulsive actions that could have negative long-term consequences.

header: ONLY ONE PARTNER WILLING TO ATTEND THERAPY

sessions.short_term_objective: Invite the partner to participate in treatment sessions.
discussion: Determine whether the client has asked his/her partner to attend therapy.
Have the client detail the context under which he/she asked the partner to attend counseling sessions (when, where, what context).

If appropriate, use role-playing techniques to help the client appropriately ask their partner to attend counseling sessions (for example, 'I care about you, and I’m concerned that our relationship is at risk. I’m going to attend therapy to work on improving our relationship, and I’d appreciate your being willing to come with me.').

sessions.short_term_objective: Verbalize any fears about informing the partner of treatment or having him/her attend sessions.
discussion: Assess potential dangers (such as fear of assault) of the client attempting to engage partner in therapy.

sessions.short_term_objective: Give permission for therapist to invite the partner to attend counseling sessions to provide information that might be useful to the presenting client’s treatment.
discussion: If the client gives permission, call the partner and invite him/her to attend sessions to provide information that might be useful to the presenting client’s treatment.

sessions.short_term_objective: Describe the origin, development, satisfaction, and present state of the relationship.
discussion: Assess the client’s history of, and satisfaction with, the relationship by conducting an interview. Appropriate questions might be: 'How did the two of you meet?' 'What attracted you to each other?' 'What qualities or characteristics did you find that you liked about your partner?' 'How did the two of you decide to get married?' 'What have been the highs and lows during dating and your marriage?'
Assess the client’s current relationship satisfaction using self-report instruments (e.g., Couples Satisfaction Inventory by Funk & Rogge; Relationship Satisfaction Questionnaire by Burns & Sayers).

sessions.short_term_objective: Describe suspicions regarding whether the nonattending partner may be having an affair.
discussion: Assess the client for the presence or suspicion of affairs (see chapters on Infidelity and Jealousy in this Planner).

sessions.short_term_objective: Verbalize any incidents of physical, sexual, or emotional abuse, or intimidation by other partner.
discussion: Assess the client for incidents of psychological, physical, or sexual aggression (see chapters on Psychological, Physical, or Sexual Abuse in this Planner), through inventories (e.g., Revised Conflict Tactics Scale by Straus et al.) and clinical interviews.

sessions.short_term_objective: Report any steps taken to dissolve the relationship.
discussion: Assess the steps taken toward divorce by administering a questionnaire (e.g., Marital Status Inventory by Weiss & Cerreto) and/or by interviewing the client about his/her sense of hope and vision for the future.

sessions.short_term_objective: Identify the pros and cons of remaining in the relationship versus separation or divorce.
discussion: Have the client state his/her point of view on (a) the pros and cons of preserving the relationship, and (b) the pros and cons of separation or divorce.

sessions.short_term_objective: Identify current problem areas in the relationship.
discussion: Assist the client in identifying the current problem areas in the relationship.

sessions.short_term_objective: Specify the problem areas that are under one’s control.
discussion: Educate the client that (a) there is evidence that an individual approach to couple problems is as effective as a conjoint approach, and (b) all individual therapy can be a form of relationship therapy, because changes instigated by one partner can change the relationship system.
Assist the client in identifying which current problems he/she has at least some influence over (e.g., communication problems, anger problems).

sessions.short_term_objective: Identify and implement behavioral changes for self that would enhance the relationship.
discussion: Have the client list changes that he/she could make to improve the relationship; review and discuss the list with the client (or assign 'How Can We Meet Each Other’s Needs and Desires?' in the Adult Psychotherapy Homework Planner, 2nd ed. by Jongsma).

Have the client rate the behaviors that he/she could perform to benefit the relationship, including estimates of both the perceived benefit and the perceived sacrifice in performing each of them (as in Weiss’ Cost/Benefit Analysis Inventory).

Arrange the client’s list of beneficial behaviors from least to greatest in terms of the amount of sacrifice that enactment would require; ask the client to perform three to five of these behaviors per week.

sessions.short_term_objective: Generate lists of preferred recreational activities that could be done alone, with their partner, or with others.
discussion: Ask the client to generate a list of desired and pleasurable activities in the following categories: (a) to be done alone, (b) to be done with partner, (c) to be done with partner and other family members, (d) to be done with partner and nonfamily members, and (e) to be done with nonfamily members (by assigning 'Identify and Schedule Pleasant Activities' in the Adult Psychotherapy Homework Planner, 2nd ed. by Jongsma or by administering the Inventory of Rewarding Activities by Weiss).

sessions.short_term_objective: Discuss with the partner the desire to increase the frequency of engaging in rewarding activities together.
discussion: Using role-playing techniques, help the client rehearse asking his/her partner to engage in positive activities together.
Assign the client to ask the partner to engage in positive activities together, and to report his/her response at the next session.

sessions.short_term_objective: Increase the number of rewarding activities that do not require participation by the partner.
discussion: Assign the client to increase the frequency of behaviors from his/her list of pleasurable activities that he/she does alone or with nonfamily members; schedule these activities in the client’s calendar for the week.

sessions.short_term_objective: Each partner constructs a self-change plan regarding an important relationship-relevant event during the week.
discussion: Teach the client the five steps of a Self-Change Plan: (1) Describe the behavior to be changed; (2) Examine the pros and cons of the current behavior; (3) Set a goal, describing as precisely as possible what is to happen; (4) Create an Action Plan, pinpointing a specific plan for enacting the goal; and (5) Evaluate enacting of the plan. Have the client practice this in session on an important relationship-relevant situation that he/she would like to change.

Ask the client to make a global evaluation of how he/she did on implementing the action plan before the next session. The rating scale is 0 = didn’t think about it or do it; 1 = thought about it; 2 = gave it a weak try; 3 = tried, partially succeeded; and 4 = did a great job. Ask them to jot down short answers to the following: What did we actually do? What positives resulted? What negatives resulted? What do we need to do from here?

sessions.short_term_objective: Verbalize an understanding of the rationale for situational analysis.
discussion: Describe for the client the goal of situational analysis (McCullogh) in the following manner: 'Although we try to get large payoffs, like having a happy marriage, these payoffs are achieved one small situation at a time. To work toward the big goals, try to make changes in the way you think and behave in small, observable situations that have a beginning, middle, and end.' Have the client repeat this rationale in his/her own words.

sessions.short_term_objective: Complete situational analysis homework to increase efficacy at affecting positive outcomes in situations at home.
discussion: Assign the client situational analysis homework that asks him/her to identify (a) a problematic situation (e.g., a description of the beginning, middle, and end of an observable situation), (b) three cognitions that occurred during the situation, (c) the client’s behavior during the situation, (d) the actual outcome and (e) the desired outcome.
Ask the client to read aloud from the situational analysis homework sheet, and paraphrase his/her statements to make sure that the client understands the key elements of the situational analysis.

sessions.short_term_objective: Identify whether one’s thoughts or conclusions promote problem resolution, are directly relevant to the situation, and are based on reality.
discussion: Have the client state whether each thought was (a) helpful in getting the desired outcome, (b) anchored to the specific situation described (i.e., is situationally-specific, not global), and (c) accurate (i.e., overt evidence can be marshaled to support it).

sessions.short_term_objective: Verbalize self-talk conclusions that promote problem resolution, are directly relevant to the situation, and are based on reality.
discussion: If any thoughts do not meet all three criteria (increase likelihood of achieving desired outcome, situationally-specific, and accurate) help the client rework the thought so that it does meet all three criteria (for example, 'She’s always on my back,' can become 'There’s something happening here that she thinks is important.').

sessions.short_term_objective: Choose desired outcomes that are achievable.
discussion: Have the client state whether the desired outcome was achievable (i.e., under his/her control); if not, help the client rework the desired outcome so that it is achievable (for example, 'I want him to listen to me when I’m upset,' can become 'I want to ask him to schedule a time for us to talk about problems that we’re having.').

sessions.short_term_objective: Verbally generate a generalizable lesson to be learned from the specific situational analysis and apply it to other situations of conflict.
discussion: Ask the client to summarize the situation by deriving a lesson to be learned from the situational analysis.
Help the client apply the lesson to other situations.

sessions.short_term_objective: Verbalize an understanding that soft emotions, such as hurt and vulnerability, precede hard or protective emotions, such as anger and resentment.
discussion: Discuss with the client the difference between 'hard' (i.e., protective) emotions, such as anger, retribution, and resentment, and 'soft' (i.e., vulnerable) emotions, such as hurt, insecurity, and fear.
When the client expresses a hard emotion, have him/her identify the soft emotions that underlie the hard emotion.

sessions.short_term_objective: Demonstrate acceptance by treating the problem as an external 'thing,' rather than blaming the partner.
discussion: Reframe for the client the problematic interactional patterns as an external problem (an 'it'), rather than as the fault of either partner.

sessions.short_term_objective: Demonstrate acceptance by listing the positive aspects of the partner’s problem-causing behavior.
discussion: Ask the client to describe the positive features of the partner’s problematic behavior (i.e., the ways the partner’s behavior actually serves a positive function in the relationship).

If the client has difficulty finding positive features, reframe the partner’s problematic behavior in terms of how it balances the client’s behavior (e.g., a hyper-responsible man may get involved with a spontaneous woman).

Explain to the client that each partner brings only one part of the balancing act to the relationship, and ask if anything can be learned from the partner’s opposite, but balancing, behavior that formerly has been upsetting to the client.

sessions.short_term_objective: Identify resources outside the relationship that can meet important personal needs.
discussion: Ask the client to list ways of satisfying their own needs outside of the relationship, to take pressure off the relationship to meet all his/her core needs; assign and schedule enactment of these need-satisfying activities and process any resistance or hurdles.

sessions.short_term_objective: Discuss and practice alternative means (i.e., those not involving problem-causing pattern) of satisfying important personal needs within the relationship.
discussion: Help the client list ways that he/she could get needs arising from soft emotions (e.g., protection, relief from hurt) met within the relationship without resorting to destructive, hard emotion-laced escalation.
Have the client role-play alternative means of satisfying needs arising from his/her soft emotions.

long_term_goals: Improve the parents’ ability to work together as a team in parenting their adolescent.
Reduce the frequency and intensity of parenting conflicts.
Increase the parents’ ability to monitor and reinforce positive adolescent behavior.
Reduce the frequency of negative adolescent behavior through consistent and effective parenting strategies.
Enhance the parents’ ability to communicate constructively about parenting issues.

sessions.short_term_objective: Identify the parents’ beliefs about adolescent behavior and parenting.
discussion: Assess the parents’ beliefs about adolescent behavior (e.g., 'Adolescents should never be disrespectful toward their parents.') via interviews and questionnaires such as Family Beliefs Inventory (Roehing & Robin) or Parent-Adolescent Relationship Questionnaire (Robin, Koepke, & Moye).

sessions.short_term_objective: Identify parenting, family, or school factors that may be contributing to the negative behavior.
discussion: Assist the parents in identifying parent-adolescent behavioral patterns that may be maintaining the adolescent’s behavior problem (e.g., unintentionally reinforcing problem behavior through nagging or emotional parenting).
Identify social context factors that may be maintaining the problem (e.g., family transitions, inconsistent rules, school or social difficulties).
Identify any parent stressors that may be maintaining the problem (e.g., unemployment, substance use, depression).

sessions.short_term_objective: Discuss how relationship functioning affects and is affected by parenting difficulties.
discussion: Have the parents indicate ways their relationship conflict has a negative impact on their adolescent’s behavior.
Have the parents describe how their adolescent’s behavior problems impact their relationship conflict.

sessions.short_term_objective: Identify the strengths and weaknesses of partners working together as a team.
discussion: Using behavioral-rehearsal techniques, have the partners attempt to solve a major parenting problem; quietly observe and note skills and deficiencies.

Review and discuss the problem-solving interaction; have partners note their strengths and weaknesses as a parenting team (or assign 'Learning to Parent as a Team' in the Adult Psychotherapy Homework Planner, 2nd ed. by Jongsma).

sessions.short_term_objective: Improve parenting knowledge by reading assigned books on parenting adolescents.
discussion: Assign the parents to read Parents and Adolescents: Living Together. Vol. I: The Basics and Vol. II: Family Problem-Solving (Patterson & Forgatch); process with the parents the principles they learned from the reading material.

sessions.short_term_objective: Monitor adolescent’s whereabouts, and identify any deficiencies in monitoring.
discussion: Assign the parents to coordinate monitoring of their adolescent’s activities, keeping track of where he/she is, whom he/she is with, what they are doing, and when they will be home; assign parents to record their joint monitoring efforts.
Have the parents discuss their successes at monitoring and to identify times and situations where the monitoring needs to be improved.

sessions.short_term_objective: Identify an adolescent behavior that partners would like to reinforce, and track its occurrence as well as antecedents and consequences.
discussion: Have the parents identify one of their adolescent’s behavior patterns that they would like to reinforce; assign them to record its occurrence every day for a week, and to note the behaviors or situations that precede it (i.e., antecedents) and follow it (i.e., consequences).

sessions.short_term_objective: Increase the frequency of contingently reinforcing positive adolescent behavior.
discussion: Help the parents decide on an appropriate reward (e.g., praise, use of the car, increase in allowance) to reinforce the positive behavior; have parents rehearse praising positive behavior patterns in session, and provide them with feedback.

sessions.short_term_objective: Increase the frequency of positive social or activity-oriented interactions with the adolescent.
discussion: Assign parents to increase the amount of focused, adolescent-centered recreational activity with the adolescent experiencing difficulty.
Assign each parent to increase the number of parent-initiated, casual, positive conversations with the adolescent experiencing difficulty.

sessions.short_term_objective: Identify a behavior in the adolescent that partners would like to discourage, and track its occurrence as well as antecedents and consequences.
discussion: Ask the parents to identify one of their adolescent’s problem behaviors that they would like to decrease; assign them to record its occurrence every day for a week, and to note the behaviors or situations that precede it (i.e., antecedents) and follow it (i.e., consequences).

sessions.short_term_objective: Establish and implement consequences (punishments) for negative adolescent behavior.
discussion: Have the parents decide on an appropriate negative consequence (e.g., loss of privilege, five-minute work chore) to contingently discourage negative behavior.

Teach the parents to establish logical and natural negative consequences to adolescent misbehavior (e.g., break curfew → lose privilege to go out; make a mess → clean up the mess); ask them to list some of these types of natural negative consequences (punishments) that could be used with their adolescent’s misbehavior.

sessions.short_term_objective: Each parent identifies, examines, and then pledges to terminate any negative behavior that he/she is modeling and that the adolescent is imitating.
discussion: If the parents are modeling for the adolescent the behavior they would like to extinguish (e.g., yelling, being sarcastic), have them contract to change their own behavior before trying to change the same behavior in the adolescent.

sessions.short_term_objective: Check with their partner regularly concerning parenting and keep a log of these interactions.
discussion: Assign the parents to confer with each other at least once a day regarding the adolescent’s behavior.
Encourage the parents to plan a mutually acceptable time to confer, to avoid casual conversations at times when arguments are likely to erupt (e.g., immediately upon arriving home in the evening).
Instruct the partners to track their satisfaction with the daily check-ins and bring in the tracking sheet to their treatment sessions.

sessions.short_term_objective: Use argument-control strategies to increase the productivity of parenting conversations.
discussion: Using modeling and behavior rehearsal, assist the partners in practicing argument control (e.g., using 'Pause, Calm, and Think'; using 'I' messages in place of 'you' messages [see chapter on Anger in this Planner]); assign partners to employ these techniques to cool off during parenting discussions if either believes that the conversation is becoming unsupportive.

sessions.short_term_objective: Report instances of constructive and supportive conversations with partner regarding current parenting experiences.
discussion: Have the partners role-play discussions they will have when the adolescent is well-behaved; have the supportive partner ask the other what the adolescent has been doing and then support his/her parenting behaviors.

Have the partners role-play discussions they will have when the adolescent displays negative behavior; have the supportive partner ask, in a supportive, nonthreatening manner, about the specifics of the misbehavior.

sessions.short_term_objective: Partners support each other’s parenting.
discussion: During role-playing exercises for dealing with adolescent misbehavior, have the supportive partner ask, in a supportive and nonthreatening manner, how the other partner dealt with the misbehavior and whether the supportive partner can do anything in the future to help.

Have the partners contract to support each other’s parenting by not interfering during the other’s parent-adolescent interactions, and by not interfering with the other’s decisions (i.e., avoiding splitting of parents’ unity).
Help the partners identify what each can do to help the other in challenging situations (e.g., when the adolescent is disrespectful).

sessions.short_term_objective: Discuss parenting disagreements only when discussion is likely to be constructive.
discussion: Have the partners contract to put disagreements over parenting strategy on hold until the situation has ended and they can meet privately, and both partners are calm and able to problem-solve without accusations or defensiveness.

sessions.short_term_objective: Regularly discuss and problem-solve parenting strategies for handling misbehavior.
discussion: Assign the partners to schedule parenting problem-solving discussions (see the chapter on Communication in this Planner) for two or three times per week.

sessions.short_term_objective: Use problem-solving skills with partner to resolve a parenting problem.
discussion: Have the partners role-play using pinpointing skills (i.e., statements that are specific, observable, and ask for increases in behavior) to specifically identify the presenting problem.

Have the partners role-play the speaker-listener technique, where the listener does not respond with their own thoughts until he/she has paraphrased the speaker’s position to that person’s satisfaction.
Advise the partners to limit themselves to solving one problem at a time.

Encourage each partner to generate at least two possible solutions to each of the adolescent’s problem behaviors, list the pros and cons of each solution, choose a solution, enact the solution, and then review and revise the solution if effectiveness is lacking.

sessions.short_term_objective: Complete situational analysis homework to increase parenting efficacy.
discussion: Assign the client situational analysis homework that asks him/her to identify (a) a problematic parenting situation (e.g., a description of the beginning, middle, and end of an observable situation); (b) three cognitions that occurred during the situation; (c) the parent’s behavior during the situation; (d) the actual outcome; and (e) the desired outcome.

sessions.short_term_objective: Identify whether one’s thoughts or conclusions promote problem resolution, are directly relevant to the situation, and are based on reality.
discussion: Have the parent state whether each thought was (a) helpful in getting the desired outcome; (b) anchored to the specific situation described (i.e., is situationally specific, not global); and (c) accurate (i.e., overt evidence can be marshaled to support it).

sessions.short_term_objective: Verbalize self-talk conclusions that promote problem resolution, are directly relevant to the situation, and are based on reality.
discussion: If any thought or conclusion fails to meet all three criteria (i.e., helpful, anchored to specific situation, accurate), help parent rework the thought so that it does meet all three criteria (for example, 'My daughter’s going to be a drug addict' can become 'Adolescents often experiment with marijuana.').

sessions.short_term_objective: Choose desired outcomes that are achievable.
discussion: Have the client state whether the desired outcome was achievable (i.e., under his/her control). If not, help client rework the desired outcome so that it is achievable. For example, 'I want my son to respect me' can become 'I will set up a family meeting to discuss how I’d like members of this family to treat each other.'

sessions.short_term_objective: Conduct regular family problem-solving meetings.
discussion: Assign parents to initiate regular family meetings for constructive problem-solving and evaluation of earlier contracts. Family meetings should be time-limited (starting with 15 minutes) and should observe set ground rules (see p. 117 of Parents and Adolescents: Living Together. Vol. II: Family Problem-Solving by Patterson & Forgatch).

Family meetings should use respectful communication skills such as taking turns talking, treating each other with respect, and no lecturing (see p. 118 of Parents and Adolescents: Living Together. Vol II: Family Problem-Solving by Patterson & Forgatch).

sessions.short_term_objective: In company with partner, establish consistent house rules.
discussion: Help the parents establish consistent house rules. Consequences for rule violation and compliance should be specified and rules can be modified and negotiated in family meetings if necessary (or assign 'Using Reinforcement Principles in Parenting' in the Adult Psychotherapy Homework Planner, 2nd ed. by Jongsma).

long_term_goals: Discuss and agree on the implementation of joint parenting strategies.
Identify parenting and contextual factors that increase the frequency of child misbehavior.
Classify and respond to child misbehavior based on function.
Have daily casual conversations about parenting.
Share ideas about parenting strategies and support each other’s parenting behavior.

sessions.short_term_objective: Discuss child problem behavior.
discussion: Have parents describe their main concerns about their child’s problem behavior, and review its history. Therapist’s questions might include: “When did the problem behavior start?” and “How has it changed across time?”

Ask parents to specifically detail the extent of the child’s problem behavior. Therapist’s questions might include: “How frequently and intensely does problem behavior occur?” “How long does it last?” “In which situations does it occur?”

Identify specific child behavior and parenting problems by having parents complete questionnaire assessments such as the Child Behavior Checklist (Achenbach) and the Parenting Scale (Arnold, O’Leary, Wolff, & Acker).
Identify (a) each partner’s parenting philosophy and strategy, and (b) each partner’s expectations for the child’s behavior (e.g., three-year-olds should sit through dinner quietly).

sessions.short_term_objective: Identify the parenting and situational factors that may be maintaining the problem.
discussion: Assist the parents in identifying parent-child behavioral patterns that may be maintaining the problem (e.g., unintentionally reinforcing problem behaviors through nagging or emotional parenting).
Identify social context factors that may be maintaining the problem (e.g., family transitions, inconsistent rules, school or social difficulties).
Identify any parent stressors that may be maintaining the problem (e.g., unemployment, substance use, depression).

sessions.short_term_objective: Discuss how relationship functioning affects and is affected by parenting difficulties.
discussion: Have parents indicate ways their relationship conflict has a negative impact on their child’s behavior.
Have parents describe how their child’s problem behavior impacts their relationship conflict.
Ask the partners to attempt to solve a major parenting problem; quietly observe and note skills and deficiencies.
Assign each parent to increase the amount of focused, child-centered positive time with the child experiencing difficulty.

sessions.short_term_objective: Verbalize an understanding of the three motives for a child’s misbehavior.
discussion: Educate parents regarding the three main motives for a child’s misbehavior: attention-seeking, escape or demands, and fun-seeking.

sessions.short_term_objective: State examples of the child’s misbehavior that are motivated by attention-seeking.
discussion: Help parents identify examples of attention-seeking misbehavior (i.e., misbehavior that only occurs when someone is around, and for which the child secures attention prior to performing).

sessions.short_term_objective: List examples of the child’s misbehavior that are motivated by escape or demand.
discussion: Help parents identify examples of demand-motivated misbehavior (i.e., misbehavior that promotes the child getting something he/she wants) and of escape-motivated misbehavior (i.e., misbehavior that promotes the child getting out of, or delaying, something he/she does not want to do).

sessions.short_term_objective: Identify examples of the child’s misbehavior that are motivated by fun-seeking.
discussion: Help parents identify examples of fun-motivated misbehavior (i.e., misbehavior that does not require someone to see it, and that the child attempts to hide).

sessions.short_term_objective: Define a behavior in the child that should be reinforced, and track its occurrence as well as antecedents and consequences.
discussion: Ask parents to select a child behavior that they would like to reinforce; assign them to record its occurrence every day for a week, and to note the behaviors or situations that precede it (i.e., antecedents) and those that follow it (i.e., consequences).

sessions.short_term_objective: Identify a behavior in the child that the parents would like to discourage, and track its occurrence as well as antecedents and consequences.
discussion: Ask parents to select a behavior that they would like to discourage; assign them to record its occurrence every day for a week and to note the behaviors or situations that precede it (i.e., antecedents) and those that follow it (i.e., consequences).

sessions.short_term_objective: Track and identify the functions of the child’s behaviors.
discussion: After reviewing the parents’ tracking sheets, have them identify the motives for each misbehavior observed (i.e., attention-seeking, demand or escape, fun-seeking).

sessions.short_term_objective: Implement ignoring responses in reaction to attention-seeking behaviors by child.
discussion: Role-play purposeful ignoring and encourage parents to use this technique to discourage attention-seeking misbehavior. Warn parents that inconsistent use of technique (e.g., ignoring misbehaviors sometimes but attending at other times) will only strengthen the misbehavior.
Help parents formulate a plan for appropriate, function-based responses to child misbehaviors (e.g., attention = ignore; demand/escape = do not give in; fun = make the behavior less fun).

sessions.short_term_objective: Implement firm control in response to escape/demand behaviors of child.
discussion: Help parents practice and troubleshoot firm, purposeful responses to demand/escape misbehavior.

sessions.short_term_objective: Implement commands and reprimands in response to fun-seeking behaviors by child.
discussion: Teach parents commands and reprimands to use in response to fun-motivated misbehavior to make the behavior less fun; responses should be firm, immediate, and brief, and they should clearly state what behavior is expected from the child. Role-play implementation of these commands.

sessions.short_term_objective: List some natural and logical negative consequences (punishments) that could flow from specific misbehavior.
discussion: Teach parents to establish logical and natural negative consequences to child misbehavior (e.g., refuse to eat → go hungry; make a mess → clean up the mess); ask them to list some of these types of natural negative consequences (punishments) that could be used with their child’s misbehavior.

sessions.short_term_objective: List ways to prevent some misbehaviors by anticipating them and planning ahead.
discussion: Have the parents list misbehavior situations that are consistently problematic; help them to identify the motivation for the misbehaviors and to brainstorm ways of preventing the misbehaviors (e.g., shorten duration of shopping trips, pack snacks for child).

sessions.short_term_objective: Report instances of effectively employing time-outs to deal with serious child misbehavior.
discussion: Help parents practice and troubleshoot responding to serious misbehavior with the time-out technique (i.e., child sits in chair with no attention for one to two minutes per year of age).

sessions.short_term_objective: Increase the frequency of contingently reinforcing positive child behavior.
discussion: Teach parents to notice and reinforce child’s positive behaviors; have each parent practice behavior reinforcement in session, and provide feedback (or assign “Using Reinforcement Principles in Parenting” in the Adult Psychotherapy Homework Planner, 2nd ed. by Jongsma).
Instruct parents in making “good behavior charts” (i.e., children earn points/tokens for appropriate behavior, and trade their points/tokens for things that they want).

sessions.short_term_objective: Increase frequency of positive interactions with child.
discussion: Assign each parent to increase amount of focused, child-centered positive time with the child experiencing difficulty.
Assign each parent to increase number of casual, positive conversations with the child experiencing difficulty.

sessions.short_term_objective: Each parent identifies, examines, and then pledges to terminate any negative behavior that he/she is modeling and that the child is imitating.
discussion: If parents are modeling for the child the behavior they would like to extinguish (e.g., yelling, hitting), have them contract to change their own behavior before trying to change the same behavior in the child.

sessions.short_term_objective: Check with partner regularly concerning parenting and keep a log of these interactions.
discussion: Assign parents to confer with each other at least once a day regarding the child’s behavior.
Encourage parents to plan a mutually acceptable time to confer, to avoid having casual conversations at times when arguments are likely to erupt (e.g., immediately upon arriving home in the evening).
Instruct partners to track their satisfaction with the daily check-ins and to bring in the tracking sheet to their treatment sessions.

sessions.short_term_objective: Use argument-control strategies to increase the productivity of parenting conversations.
discussion: Assist the partners in practicing argument control (e.g., using “Pause, Calm, and Think”; using “I” messages in place of “you” messages [see chapter on Anger in this Planner]); assign partners to employ these techniques to cool off during parenting discussions if either believes that the conversation is becoming unsupportive).

sessions.short_term_objective: Report instances of constructive and supportive conversations with partner regarding current parenting experiences.
discussion: Help partners role-play discussions they will have when the children are well-behaved; have the supportive partner ask the other what the children have been doing and then support his/her parenting behaviors.

Help partners role-play discussions they will have when the children are poorly behaved; have the supportive partner ask, in a supportive, nonthreatening manner, about the specifics of the misbehavior.

During role-playing exercises for dealing with child misbehavior, have the supportive partner ask in a supportive, nonthreatening manner about how the other dealt with the misbehavior and whether the supportive partner can do anything in the future to help (or assign “Learning to Parent as a Team” in the Adult Psychotherapy Homework Planner, 2nd ed. by Jongsma).

sessions.short_term_objective: Agree with partner to support each other’s parenting.
discussion: Have partners contract to support each other’s parenting by not interfering during the other’s parent-child interactions, and by not interfering with the other’s decisions (i.e., avoiding splitting of parents’ unity).
Help partners identify what each can do to help the other in challenging situations (e.g., play with or supervise the children while the other partner is on the phone).

Have partners contract to put disagreements over parenting strategy on hold until the situation has ended and they can meet privately, and both partners are calm and able to problem-solve without accusations or defensiveness.

sessions.short_term_objective: Regularly discuss and problem-solve parenting strategies for handling misbehavior.
discussion: Assign partners to schedule parenting problem-solving discussions (see the chapter on Communication in this Planner) for two or three times per week.

sessions.short_term_objective: Use problem-solving skills with partner to resolve a parenting problem.
discussion: Assign partners to schedule parenting problem-solving discussions for two or three times per week.
Have the partners role-play using pinpointing skills to specifically identify the problem.
Help partners role-play the speaker-listener technique, where the listener does not respond with their own thoughts until he/she has paraphrased the speaker’s position to that person’s satisfaction.
Advise partners to limit themselves to solving one problem at a time.

sessions.short_term_objective: Brainstorm with partner several possible parental interventions for the misbehavior.
discussion: Encourage each partner to generate at least two possible solutions to each of the child’s problem behaviors.

sessions.short_term_objective: Evaluate with the partner various possible solutions to the child’s problematic behavior, choose one, and plan for its enactment and evaluation.
discussion: Help partners role-play choosing a solution together by judging the advantages and disadvantages of each possible solution.
Help partners plan together on how to enact solutions.
Have partners establish a time to review the progress of the solution, and to troubleshoot the solution as necessary.

sessions.short_term_objective: Establish consistent house rules.
discussion: Have parents discuss and establish consistent house rules (or assign “Using Reinforcement Principles in Parenting” in the Adult Psychotherapy Homework Planner, 2nd ed. by Jongsma).

long_term_goals: Partners reach compromises that are acceptable to each.
One partner makes significant changes in style of relating.
Partners capitalize on their personality differences to enhance the relationship.
Partners accept certain personality differences and respect those differences.

sessions.short_term_objective: Describe own and partner’s personality styles and differentiate long-standing personality styles from recent habitual patterns.
discussion: Have each partner develop a list of own personality styles that are similar to those of partner.
Help partners differentiate between habits (i.e., changeable behaviors) and personality styles (i.e., long-standing ways of approaching the world).
Ask each partner to develop a list of their own personality styles that differ significantly from those of their partner.
Ask each partner to develop a list of the partner’s important habits.
Ask each partner to develop a list of their own important habits.

sessions.short_term_objective: Describe personality differences that have enriched the relationship.
discussion: Ask each partner to describe how differences between self and partner enrich the relationship.

sessions.short_term_objective: Acknowledge how differences in personality make social life more interesting.
discussion: Help each partner identify how differences between self and partner are valuable and help in social functioning.

sessions.short_term_objective: Describe personality differences that have caused conflict in the relationship.
