discussion: Ask each partner to describe how differences between self and partner are detrimental to the relationship.
Ask each partner to describe how differences between self and partner are detrimental to social functioning.

sessions.short_term_objective: Agree to make some changes in habitual behavior.
discussion: Request that each partner identify and verbally commit to changing habitual patterns that are offensive to the other partner.

sessions.short_term_objective: Agree to attempt changing a behavior that seems to represent a long-standing personality style.
discussion: Request that each partner identify and verbally commit to changing behaviors that represent long-standing personality patterns and cause conflicts in the relationship (or assign “Positive and Negative Contributions to the Relationship: Yours and Mine” in the Adult Psychotherapy Homework Planner, 2nd ed. by Jongsma).

sessions.short_term_objective: Verbalize how personality differences in parents model very different behaviors for children.
discussion: Help the partners understand the value of differences in the relationship for rearing children.

sessions.short_term_objective: Verbalize acceptance of differences in personality styles between self and partner, and cite the value of some differences.
discussion: Assist the partners in understanding the value of differences in the relationship for intimate functioning.
Assist the partners in developing an understanding of the types of behavior that are very difficult to change.
Teach the partners about the types of personality styles that are very difficult to change.
Assist the partners in accepting differences that can exist between them without any detriment to each other.
Educate the partners regarding the value of their differences in personality.

sessions.short_term_objective: Make positive comments to partner about the differences in personality styles.
discussion: Ask the partners to make comments to each other in therapy session about the value of their differences.

sessions.short_term_objective: Make positive comments to family/friends about differences in personality styles.
discussion: Assign the partners to make comments to family/friends about the value of their differences.

long_term_goals: Terminate verbal and/or psychological abuse and establish a relationship based in respect and a desire for mutual enhancement.
Replace hostile, threatening, and critical comments with respectful communication that builds self-esteem.
Eliminate threats to leave the relationship and/or to have sex with others.
Eliminate the use of controlling behaviors that attempt to keep the partner physically nearby and away from friends and family.
Eliminate the use of controlling behaviors that attempt to keep the partner from bettering herself/himself.
Evaluate alternatives to current relationship.

sessions.short_term_objective: Verbalize agreement to stop hostile comments and name-calling.
discussion: Obtain verbal commitment from the partners not to engage in name-calling or making hostile comments.
Advise the partners of the need for individual therapy if anger cannot be controlled in the conjoint therapy sessions.

Discuss with the partners the need for both to be psychologically ready before conjoint therapy is indicated, and to accept responsibility for minimizing any major negative events that might occur in therapy.

sessions.short_term_objective: Identify partner’s comments that are especially damaging to self-esteem.
discussion: Have each partner describe comments by partner that hurt him/her the most.
Have each partner describe the areas of his/her own life where he/she feels most vulnerable.

sessions.short_term_objective: Verbalize an understanding of the negative impact of abuse.
discussion: Using role-reversal technique, have the abusive partner assume abused partner’s identity and then identify the emotional impact of the abusive behavior (or assign 'Letter of Apology' in the Adult Psychotherapy Homework Planner, 2nd ed. by Jongsma).

Confront any displays of or references to abusive behavior, and educate the partners regarding its destructive consequences (or assign 'Alternatives to Destructive Anger' in the Adult Psychotherapy Homework Planner, 2nd ed. by Jongsma).

sessions.short_term_objective: Verbally agree not to use psychological coercion or threat of physical force to obtain sexual interaction.
discussion: Obtain commitment from the partners not to use physical force to coerce sexual interaction.
Educate the partners that to have a positive sexual relationship, the sexual activity must be acceptable to both the partners.

sessions.short_term_objective: Identify the negative consequences of using coercion for sexual activity.
discussion: Educate the partners that pressure by one partner to engage in sexual activity usually leads to sexual aversions and/or avoidance and dislike by the other partner.

Educate the partners that sexual behavior is one of the most sensitive of all human behaviors, and that aversive control by one partner can quickly lead to disinterest and sexual dysfunction in the other partner.

sessions.short_term_objective: Terminate threats to have sex with someone else.
discussion: Obtain verbal commitment from the partners not to threaten to have sex with someone else.

sessions.short_term_objective: Terminate threats to leave partner.
discussion: Obtain verbal commitment from the partners not to threaten to leave the relationship during the term of therapy; an agreement about the length of therapy should be developed at the beginning of treatment.

sessions.short_term_objective: Terminate all threats of physical aggression against the partner for any reason.
discussion: Obtain a verbal commitment from the partners not to engage in any physical force against the other partner for any reason; be aware that when intense verbal intimidation exists, the risk for physical aggression also is high.

sessions.short_term_objective: Describe instances of coercion or threats of physical violence in the relationship.
discussion: Ask both partners to describe the extent to which psychological coercion and threats of violence are present in the relationship in general.
Ask both partners to describe the perceived or experienced negative consequences of threatened violence.

sessions.short_term_objective: Abused, fearful partner accepts a referral to a safe environment.
discussion: If the abused partner’s fear of violence is intense, provide a referral to a safe environment (e.g., battered-women’s shelter, abuse hot-line number).

sessions.short_term_objective: Verbalize an understanding of male control and misuse of power in our society.
discussion: Review and discuss with the partners the role of patriarchy in American society.
Review and discuss with the partners how the controlling partner misuses his/her power.
Educate the partners regarding how controlling behaviors by one partner lead to dislike and avoidance by the other partner.

sessions.short_term_objective: Both the partners agree to build each other’s self-esteem through compliments, appreciation, and acts of kindness.
discussion: Review with partners the evidence regarding the association between psychological aggression and poor self-esteem and/or depression; have the partners list specific ways for them to build self-esteem in each other (or assign 'How Can We Meet Each Other’s Needs and Desires?' in the Adult Psychotherapy Homework Planner, 2nd ed. by Jongsma).

sessions.short_term_objective: Agree to accept and encourage contact by both the partners with friends and family as a means of improving the relationship.
discussion: Educate the partners regarding the fact that external social support (e.g., contact with friends) and relationship satisfaction are positively related.

sessions.short_term_objective: Agree to support each other in obtaining training or education.
discussion: Educate the partners regarding the need for each partner to be able to venture out from the relationship with the sense that the other will be supportive of him/her (i.e., for bettering self through education or training or job enhancement).

sessions.short_term_objective: Abusive partner identifies feelings that motivate controlling behavior.
discussion: Have the abusive partner identify the feelings (e.g., jealousy, fears of inadequacy) that underlie the need for controlling behavior of either partner.

sessions.short_term_objective: List the negative consequences of exerting control over the other partner.
discussion: Assist the partners in listing the negative consequences of controlling behavior on the abused partner (e.g., resentment, avoidance, waning of caring feelings).

sessions.short_term_objective: Demonstrate respectful, accurate communication with their partner.
discussion: Have each partner listen to the other about a relationship matter without interrupting, and then paraphrase what the other said.
Provide feedback and interpretation to the partners about their communication styles.

sessions.short_term_objective: Assess alternatives to the relationship and accept referrals regarding respite from the relationship.
discussion: In an individual session with the psychologically abused partner, have him/her evaluate the available alternatives to the current relationship.
If necessary, refer psychologically abused partner to an agency for battered women and/or to a shelter.

sessions.short_term_objective: Abused partner read material on abusive relationships and building self-esteem.
discussion: Suggest reading materials for the abused partner on abusive relationships and building self-esteem (e.g., The Verbally Abusive Relationship by Evans; Surviving Domestic Violence by Weiss; The Dance of Anger by Lerner; Ten Days to Self-Esteem! by Burns).

sessions.short_term_objective: Both partners agree to minimize negative relationship interactions in the presence of their children.
discussion: If the partners have children, review with the partners the evidence showing a significant link between open hostility between parents and psychopathology in children (i.e., increased incidence of conduct problems and anxiety problems).
If the partners have children, have both partners commit to minimizing negative interactions in the presence of the children.

long_term_goals: Identify and plan regular positive activities, to be enjoyed both alone and together.
Discuss and respect each other’s varying interests.
Find opportunities to enjoy elements of each other’s hobbies or interests as a means of giving of self to the other partner.
Plan vacation opportunities in a manner that maximizes mutual enjoyment and minimizes conflict.

sessions.short_term_objective: Verbally define current level of satisfaction with recreational activities.
discussion: Identify each partner’s level of satisfaction with recreational activities that are done (a) individually and (b) as a couple.
Ask each partner to identify elements of recreational activities that he/she believes are in need of improvement (i.e., frequency, quality, particular activities).

sessions.short_term_objective: Generate lists of recreational activities that each partner would like to do alone, with partner, or with others.
discussion: Ask the partners to complete the Inventory of Rewarding Activities (Birchler & Weiss, 1977) to generate a list of desired activities in the following categories: (a) to do alone, (b) to do with partner, (c) to do with partner and other family members, (d) to do with partner and nonfamily members, and (e) to do with nonfamily members.

Ask the partners to discuss the similarities and differences of their Rewarding Activities lists; assist them in identifying interests that are shared with partner and those that are unique to each partner.

sessions.short_term_objective: Discuss and listen in a respectful manner to other partner’s leisure-time likes and dislikes.
discussion: For important activities about which partners disagree, have partners discuss their points of view by taking turns as speakers (for example, “When I go hunting, I feel alive and part of nature.”).
After the speaker states his/her preferences, have the listener show respect for the other’s point of view by paraphrasing it and by refraining from criticism.

sessions.short_term_objective: Identify and plan pleasurable activities of varying lengths.
discussion: Assign each partner to independently list 5 to 10 activities or behaviors that he/she could do that the other partner would enjoy.
Have each person classify the partner-enjoyable activities into those that can be done in 15–30 minutes, 1–2 hours, 4–6 hours, a full day, and a weekend.
Have partners use their lists of rewarding activities to schedule one week’s activities (e.g., work, responsibilities, chores, and leisure pursuits).

sessions.short_term_objective: Discuss the impact of planned pleasurable activities and contract for continued weekly planning.
discussion: Ask each partner to discuss the week’s pleasurable activity assignment using “I” statements (for example, “When we went for a walk at the beach this weekend, I felt really peaceful and close to you. I’d like us to go for a walk at least once a weekend in the future.”); have the listener respond using paraphrasing and reflecting skills.
After reviewing and troubleshooting the pleasurable activity assignment, have partners contract to schedule their activities weekly.

sessions.short_term_objective: Each partner construct a self-change plan regarding recreational pursuit differences.
discussion: Teach partners the five steps of a Self-Change Plan: (1) Describe the behavior to be changed; (2) Examine the pros and cons of the current behavior; (3) Set a goal, describing as precisely as possible what is to happen; (4) Create Action Plan, pinpointing a specific plan for enacting the goal; and (5) Evaluate the enacting of a plan. Have the partners practice this in session on an aspect of recreational pursuit differences that each would like to change.

Ask partners to make a global evaluation of how they did on the action plan before the next session. The rating scale is 0 = didn’t think about it or do it; 1 = thought about it; 2 = gave it a weak try; 3 = tried, partially succeeded; and 4 = did a great job. Ask them to jot down short answers to the following: What did we actually do? What positives resulted? What negatives resulted? What do we need to do from here?

sessions.short_term_objective: Each partner identifies an activity that is primarily enjoyable to the other partner that he/she can occasionally show an interest in or participate in.
discussion: Assign each partner to join in or arrange for, the other partner, at least three activities that are enjoyable for the other partner (scaled to fit their time demands) per week; have partners record the activity and rate the quality of satisfaction.
Encourage each partner to commit to occasionally showing an interest or participating in an activity (e.g., attending a symphony concert) that is pleasurable to the other partner but not to self.
Have partners contract to respect each other’s interests and hobbies by not criticizing the other’s hobby or other enjoyable activity.

sessions.short_term_objective: Each partner pursue an activity that is pleasurable to him/her while not allowing the activity to dominate the couple’s available free time.
discussion: Have partners contract to respect each other by not letting any one activity or hobby dominate own free time or the couple’s available free time.
Have partners contract to respect each other’s interests and hobbies by scheduling time each week for mutually enjoyable and individually enjoyable leisure activities.

sessions.short_term_objective: Use problem-solving skills to find agreement on how both partners can enjoy a vacation site.
discussion: If partners disagree on vacation sites (e.g., one likes the beach and the other does not), help them use problem-solving skills so each generates at least two ways in which they can still enjoy mutual destinations (e.g., one goes to the beach while the other shops in nearby town).

If partners disagree on vacation sites, help them each generate at least two ways to include others and thereby increase the attractiveness of the partner’s preferred site (e.g., vacationing with another family to provide each partner with company to share favorite pursuits).

sessions.short_term_objective: Agree to spend equal time together at one partner’s choice, followed by time together at other partner’s choice.
discussion: If partners disagree on vacation sites, help them each generate at least two ways to make destination choices equitable (e.g., one summer go to the beach, the next to the mountains).

sessions.short_term_objective: Plan and periodically implement a high-intensity day of positive activities that focus alternately on each partner’s wishes.
discussion: Have partners plan a “love day” periodically, during which one partner receives from the other partner as many beneficial activities (especially benefits that don’t occur on typical days) as possible (for example, a husband might give his wife a backrub, take care of the children while she exercises, and then prepare a romantic, candlelight dinner).
Ask partners to alternate who will be the recipient of “love day” and who will be the giver.

long_term_goals: Resolve conflicts over religious and spiritual beliefs, values, and practices.
Develop mutual respect for each other’s religious and spiritual beliefs, values, and practices.
Negotiate agreements regarding religious and spiritual practices that both partners can accept and support.

sessions.short_term_objective: Identify when the partners’ conflict over religious and spiritual beliefs, values, or activities began.
discussion: Ask the partners to describe when and how they argue or disagree about religious and spiritual beliefs, values, and activities.

sessions.short_term_objective: Each partner identifies how his/her religious and spiritual beliefs strengthen the relationship.
discussion: Ask each client to describe ways in which his/her religious and spiritual beliefs, values, and activities strengthen the relationship.

sessions.short_term_objective: Each partner identifies how the couple’s religious differences cause conflict in other areas of the relationship.
discussion: Ask each client to describe the ways in which religious and spiritual differences accentuate conflict in other areas of the relationship (e.g., role strain, parenting).

sessions.short_term_objective: Promise respect for other partner’s religious and spiritual beliefs, values, or activities, and agree not to coerce other partner into belief conformity.
discussion: Have the clients contract to respect each other’s religious and spiritual beliefs by not criticizing the other’s beliefs, values, or activities.
Have clients contract to respect each other’s religious and spiritual beliefs by agreeing not to coerce the other into conforming to self’s beliefs, values, or activities.

sessions.short_term_objective: Share the meaning of commitment, respect, intimacy, forgiveness, and sexuality within each partner’s religious and spiritual belief system.
discussion: Ask each partner to discuss the values placed on (a) commitment, (b) respect, (c) intimacy, and (d) forgiveness within the framework of his/her religious and/or spiritual belief system.
Help the partners identify the impact that their differing religious and spiritual beliefs have on their sexual relationship.

sessions.short_term_objective: Share how the meaning of commitment, respect, intimacy, forgiveness, and sexuality within each partner’s religious and spiritual belief system is evidenced within the relationship.
discussion: Have each partner discuss how the values placed on (a) commitment, (b) respect, (c) intimacy, and (d) forgiveness provide evidence of his/her religious and or spiritual belief.

sessions.short_term_objective: Each partner articulates own core beliefs, including the meaning of human existence.
discussion: Help each partner identify own core beliefs (e.g., the existence and nature of God, the nature of man, the meaning of human life, the existence and nature of an afterlife) and how he/she came to that belief system.

sessions.short_term_objective: Each partner shares how own core beliefs have helped to provide meaning to his/her personal life.
discussion: Have each partner consider and share the ways that religious and spiritual beliefs have added meaning to his/her personal life.

sessions.short_term_objective: Verbalize how religious beliefs and practice are important for support of core beliefs.
discussion: Have each partner consider and share the ways that religious and spiritual beliefs and practices reinforce his/her core beliefs.

sessions.short_term_objective: Demonstrate respect for the other partner’s professed religious and spiritual beliefs by engaging in listener behaviors that facilitate the free exchange of views regarding the meaning of human existence.
discussion: Ask the listening partner to show respect for the speaker’s beliefs by paraphrasing the speaker’s beliefs, even if he/she does not agree with the speaker.
Ask the listening partner to show respect for the speaker’s beliefs by not responding with lecturing or preaching, even if he/she does not agree with the speaker.
Ask the listening partner to show respect for the speaker’s beliefs by not arguing against the speaker’s beliefs.

sessions.short_term_objective: Verbalize reasons why it is important to self that the other partner agree in religious beliefs and practice; then offer constructive ways to respond to the ongoing disagreement.
discussion: Allow each partner who so desires to describe (a) why it is important for him/her that the other partner accept and adopt his/her religious beliefs, and (b) how he/she will constructively cope with a lack of agreement between them.

sessions.short_term_objective: Identify the degree of flexibility available for accommodating divergent beliefs.
discussion: Help each partner identify what deviations from core beliefs he/she can accommodate or tolerate in the other partner.
Help each partner identify what deviations from core beliefs he/she cannot accommodate or tolerate in the other partner.
Have each partner identify his/her core belief regarding divorce.

sessions.short_term_objective: Teach the partners how to construct a self-change plan and ask each to construct one regarding religious differences.
discussion: Teach the partners the five steps of a Self-Change Plan: (1) Describe the behavior to be changed; (2) Examine the pros and cons of the current behavior; (3) Set a goal, describing as precisely as possible what is to happen; (4) Create an Action Plan, pinpointing a specific plan for enacting the goal; and (5) Evaluate enacting of the plan. Have the partners practice this in session on an aspect of religious differences that each would like to change.

Ask the partners to make a global evaluation of how they did on the action plan before the next session. The rating scale is 0 = didn’t think about it or do it; 1 = thought about it; 2 = gave it a weak try; 3 = tried, partially succeeded; and 4 = did a great job. Ask them to jot down short answers to the following: What did we actually do? What positives resulted? What negatives resulted? What do we need to do from here?

sessions.short_term_objective: Verbalize an understanding of the rationale for situational analysis.
discussion: Describe for the partners the goal of situational analysis in the following manner: 'Accommodating to each other’s religious beliefs happens one small situation at a time. To work toward the big goals, try to make changes in the way you think and behave in small, observable situations that have a beginning, middle, and end.' Have client repeat rationale in his/her own words.

sessions.short_term_objective: Complete situational analysis homework to increase efficacy at affecting positive outcomes in situations at home.
discussion: Assign the partners situational analysis homework that asks each to identify (a) a problematic situation (e.g., a description of the beginning, middle, and end of an observable situation); (b) three cognitions that occurred during the situation; (c) the behavior during the situation; (d) the actual outcome; and (e) the desired outcome.

Ask each partner to read aloud from the situational analysis homework sheet, and paraphrase his/her statements to make sure that the therapist understands the key elements of the situational analysis.

sessions.short_term_objective: Identify whether self-talk thoughts or conclusions promote problem resolution, are directly relevant to the situation, and are based on reality.
discussion: Have each partner state whether each thought in his/her situational analysis was (a) helpful in getting the desired outcome; (b) anchored to the specific situation described (i.e., is situationally-specific, not global); and (c) accurate (i.e., overt evidence can be marshaled to support it).

sessions.short_term_objective: Verbalize self-talk conclusions that promote problem resolution, are directly relevant to the situation, and are based on reality.
discussion: If any thought or conclusion fails to meet all three criteria (i.e., helpful, anchored to specific situation, accurate), have the partner rework the thought or conclusion so that it does meet all three criteria. For example, 'He doesn’t care about me because he won’t go to my church,' can become 'He has different beliefs and trying to force him to come with me is counterproductive.'

sessions.short_term_objective: Choose desired outcomes that are achievable.
discussion: Have the partner state whether the desired outcome was achievable (i.e., under his/her control). If not, help him/her rework the desired outcome so that it is achievable. For example, 'I want him to come to church with me,' can become 'I will invite him to come to the Bible study on Wednesday night.'

sessions.short_term_objective: Verbally generate a generalizable lesson to be learned from the specific situational analysis and apply it to other situations of conflict over religion.
discussion: Ask the partner to summarize the situation by deriving a lesson to be learned from the situational analysis and whether the lesson can be applied to other situations.

sessions.short_term_objective: List the perceived advantages and disadvantages of belief-based community social activities.
discussion: Have both partners address the advantages and disadvantages of the sense of community brought to the relationship by either partner’s religious and spiritual activities.

sessions.short_term_objective: Verbalize any explicit agreements that were made regarding the children’s religious training before they were born and the current feelings about those agreements.
discussion: If the couple has children, identify whether an explicit agreement regarding their religious training was reached prior to their birth.
If either partner has misgivings about the original agreement about the children’s religious upbringing, have him/her verbalize that position using nonblaming 'I' statements.

sessions.short_term_objective: Each partner states his/her current wishes for the religious training of the children.
discussion: Have each partner verbalize his/her current expectations for the children’s religious instruction or practice.

sessions.short_term_objective: Reach an agreement on the children’s religious training that each partner can accept and support.
discussion: Using communication and problem resolution skills (see chapter on Communication in this Planner), ask the partners to negotiate an agreement regarding their children’s religious instruction and practice that both partners can abide by.

sessions.short_term_objective: Identify the effects that the partners’ religious and spiritual differences have on parenting.
discussion: If the couple has children, identify whether either’s religious and/or spiritual beliefs guide his/her approach to discipline.
If religious and spiritual beliefs guide either partner’s parenting practices, have both discuss the strengths and conflicts arising from that approach.

long_term_goals: Reduce symptoms of depression and anxiety related to ambiguity of direction and values in life.
Recognize advantages that usually come only with maturity and retirement.
Partners communicate about feelings and resolve problems without escalating hostility.
Become connected or reconnected to partner, family members, volunteer opportunities, and/or religious community.
Express increased satisfaction with sexual relationship.
Develop accepting attitudes toward changes in the intensity and frequency of sexual activity across a life span.

sessions.short_term_objective: Express, verbally and in writing, overall level of relationship dissatisfaction and the specific areas of dissatisfaction.
discussion: Assess current level of relationship satisfaction, using interview and/or self-report instruments (e.g., Couples Satisfaction Inventory by Funk & Rogge, Relationship Satisfaction Questionnaire by Burns & Sayers, or the Marital Satisfaction Inventory-Revised by Snyder); provide feedback regarding test results.

sessions.short_term_objective: Identify the strengths and needs of the relationship.
discussion: Have partners identify the strengths and needs of the relationship via interviews and questionnaires (e.g., Revised Conflict Tactics Scale by Straus et al., Conflicts and Problem-Solving Scales by Kerig, or the Sexual History Form by LoPiccolo); provide feedback regarding test results.

sessions.short_term_objective: Describe the origin, development, satisfaction, and present state of the relationship.
discussion: Assess the partners’ history of, and satisfaction with, the relationship by interviewing the couple; appropriate questions might be: “How did the two of you meet?” “What attracted you to each other?” “What qualities or characteristics did you find that you liked about your partner?” “How did the two of you decide to get married?” “What have been the highs and lows of your marriage?”

Assess the partners’ current satisfaction with their adjustment to retirement by interviewing the couple; appropriate questions might be “How was the adjustment to retirement?” “How did the two of you plan for what your lives would be like?” “What do you like about the way your lives are now?” “What changes would you make in your retirement life?”

sessions.short_term_objective: Report any steps taken to dissolve the relationship.
discussion: Assess the steps taken toward divorce by administering a questionnaire (e.g., Marital Status Inventory by Weiss & Cerreto) and/or by interviewing the client about his/her sense of hope and vision for the future.
Have the client state his/her point of view on (a) the pros and cons of preserving the relationship, and (b) the pros and cons of separation or divorce.

sessions.short_term_objective: Identify current problem areas and changes that self and other partner could make to improve the relationship and/or retirement life.
discussion: Have the partners identify the current problem areas in the relationship or retirement life.

Assign each partner to list changes for self and the other partner that would improve the relationship and their life of retirement (e.g., modified instructions for the “Areas of Change” questionnaire by Weiss and Birchler, or assign “Positive and Negative Contributions to the Relationship: Mine and Yours” in the Adult Psychotherapy Homework Planner, 2nd ed. by Jongsma); review and discuss the lists in session.

sessions.short_term_objective: Identify specific communication deficits.
discussion: Have the couple attempt to solve a major problem while the therapist quietly watches and takes notes about communication skills and deficits.

Praise the couple for things they do well (such as making eye contact or attempting to define the problem) and provide direct feedback regarding things that need improvement (such as maintaining a civil tone of voice or overcoming a tendency to interrupt).

sessions.short_term_objective: Verbalize the thoughts that are associated with anxiety and worry over the future.
discussion: Probe for cognitive distortions that lead to anxiety and uneasiness around their retirement and future.

Assign homework to track events/thoughts that precipitate anxious and depressed feelings for use in situational analyses (e.g., “Negative Thoughts Trigger Negative Feelings” in the Adult Psychotherapy Homework Planner, 2nd ed. by Jongsma).

sessions.short_term_objective: Organize a list of thoughts, behaviors, actual outcomes, and desired outcomes via situational analysis of retirement transition-problem experiences.
discussion: Demonstrate how to organize a situational analysis. Have each client choose from his/her homework specific retirement-related problem-eliciting situations and tell what his/her interpretations/cognitions were, what his/her behavior was, and what the actual outcome of the situation was.
As the concluding step in the situational analysis, have the client describe what his/her desired outcome was in the specified situation.

sessions.short_term_objective: Verbalize thoughts that were unhelpful, global, or inaccurate, and then state more beneficial self-talk.
discussion: Help the client determine whether each thought was (a) accurate, (b) anchored to the specific situation, and (c) helpful in getting the desired outcome.

If any thoughts are not accurate, anchored, and helpful in achieving the desired outcome, have the client rework the thoughts so they meet criteria. (For example, “I don’t have a purpose to my days without a job to go to” can become “I now have time to make contributions to my family and community that I never had while working.”)

sessions.short_term_objective: Partners implement the two overarching communication skills of: “Be Clear” and “Be Considerate.”
discussion: Teach the partners communication skills that emphasize that interchanges should be (a) clear (i.e., be specific, share thoughts and feelings, pay attention, ask clarifying questions, summarize content and feelings); and (b) considerate (i.e., include positives, show consideration when expressing negatives, let partner know that one is listening even if one disagrees, reserve judgment).
Ask the partners to discuss a low-conflict area of desired change and ask them to rate how well they did being clear.
Ask the partners to discuss a low-conflict area of desired change and ask them to rate how well they did being considerate.

sessions.short_term_objective: Practice defining problems in specific, nonblaming terms.
discussion: Have the partners take turns pinpointing problems (that is, making requests for changes that are specific, observable, and ask for increases rather than decreases in the other partner’s behavior).

Have the partners use the “speaker-listener” technique, with the listener trying to convey understanding after the speaker makes an “I” statements in the following form: “When ______ happens, I feel ______. I would like ______.”
If either partner is mind reading the other, have him/her rephrase statements so that he/she is speaking only for self and expressing their own perceptions.

sessions.short_term_objective: Practice sharing thoughts and feelings in a manner that promotes intimacy.
discussion: Have partners share their feelings regarding issues about which they’d like to be closer; provide a list of “emotion” words, if necessary, to cue partners to the subtleties of words expressing feelings.

sessions.short_term_objective: Articulate the values and goals for living a meaningful life using Covey’s four human needs and the approach taken to fulfill those needs.
discussion: Ask the partners to read First Things First (Covey, Merrill, & Merrill), which posits that cross-cultural wisdom literature contains four key human needs “to live, to love, to learn, to leave a legacy.”

Ask the partners to consider their approach to fulfilling the need “to live” (“Our physical need for such things as food, clothing, economic well-being, health,” Covey et al., p. 45) by having them write and discuss (a) their past and current goals for meeting financial needs, and (b) the pros and cons of their current approach.

Ask the partners to consider their approach to fulfilling the need “to love” (“Our social need to relate to other people, to belong, to love, to be loved,” Covey et al., p. 45) by having them write and discuss (a) their past and current goals for having rich, satisfying relationships with others, and (b) the pros and cons of their current approach.

Ask the partners to consider their approach to fulfilling the need “to learn” (“Our mental need to develop and to grow,” Covey et al., p. 45) by having them write and discuss (a) their past and current goals for learning, growing, and being open to new experiences and skills, and (b) the pros and cons of their current approach.

Ask the partners to consider their approach to fulfilling the need “to leave a legacy” (“Our spiritual need to have a sense of meaning, purpose, personal congruence, and contribution,” Covey et al., p. 45) by having them write and discuss (a) their past and current goals for having a sense of direction and purpose, and (b) the pros and cons of their current approach.

sessions.short_term_objective: Verbally define current level of satisfaction with recreational activities.
discussion: Identify each partner’s level of satisfaction with recreational activities that are done (a) individually and (b) as a couple.
Ask each partner to identify elements of recreational activities that he/she believes are in need of improvement (i.e., frequency, quality, particular activities).

sessions.short_term_objective: Generate lists of recreational activities that each partner would like to do alone, with partner, or with others.
discussion: Ask partners to complete the Inventory of Rewarding Activities (Birchler & Weiss, 1977) to generate a list of desired activities in the following categories: (a) to do alone, (b) to do with partner, (c) to do with partner and other family members, (d) to do with partner and nonfamily members, and (e) to do with nonfamily members.

Ask partners to discuss the similarities and differences of their Rewarding Activities lists; assist them in identifying interests that are shared with partner and those that are unique to each partner.

sessions.short_term_objective: Describe the history of the sexual relationship and identify any problems.
discussion: Assess the frequency of sexual interactions across the history of the relationship.
Assess the partners’ enjoyment of sexual interactions across the history of the relationship.

sessions.short_term_objective: Describe the positive aspects of the physical/sexual relationship.
discussion: Ask the partners to describe the positive sexual aspects of their current relationship.

sessions.short_term_objective: Identify sexual expectations in the relationship and how they have changed in retirement.
discussion: Have each client describe how expectations about his/her sexual life have changed.
Assist the clients in interpreting how the frequency and satisfaction of their sexual encounters correspond to that of others of their ages.

sessions.short_term_objective: Identify and resolve, if possible, any physical disorder or medication that is inhibiting sexual desire.
discussion: Assess role of any known or possible existing physical condition (e.g., diabetes, substance abuse, depression, anxiety disorders) or medication (e.g., antihypertensive medication, antidepressant medication) that could interfere with sexual functioning.
If clients report erectile dysfunction, ask male client to talk to a physician about receiving medication to help achieve satisfying erections (e.g., Viagra, Cialis, Levitra).

sessions.short_term_objective: Report an increase in sexual thoughts and/or fantasy when not engaged in sexual activity with partner.
discussion: Request that clients indulge in sexual fantasies that increase sexual desire toward partner.

sessions.short_term_objective: Read books and/or watch educational videos on sexual functioning and sexuality.
discussion: If religious views permit, encouraged clients to purchase educational videos for enjoyable sex in later years (e.g., “Great Sex Over 50” DVD Set, Sinclair Institute) (see references for videos in Bibliography).

Suggest that the clients read books on sexual behavior and sexual functioning, such as Sex for Dummies (Westheimer, 1995) or Coping with Erectile Dysfunction: How to Regain Confidence and Enjoy Great Sex (Metz & McCarthy).

sessions.short_term_objective: Engage in sensate focus activity alone and with partner.
discussion: Instruct the clients in use of sensate focus (i.e., at first, taking turns providing sensual touch without genital or breast contact; later, adding genital and breast stimulation).

sessions.short_term_objective: Discuss sensate focus activities with the partner in therapy sessions, and change sexual stimulation activities based on feedback from partner.
discussion: Obtain feedback from the clients about the sensate focus exercises, and assist in minimizing any behaviors that affect either partner negatively.

long_term_goals: Evaluate the possibility of resolving the differences and review the pros and cons of remaining married.
Consistently uphold “the best interests of the children” as paramount and act accordingly, regardless of the final fate of the marriage.
Learn healthy ways to manage and express anger.
Learn to cope with the confusion and varied losses that separation entails.
Cooperate in reaching a reasonable separation and fair divorce agreement.
Reduce conflict, hurt, and angry feelings.
Establish and maintain healthy co-parenting practices.

sessions.short_term_objective: Express, verbally and in writing, overall level of relationship dissatisfaction and the specific areas of dissatisfaction.
discussion: Assess current level of relationship satisfaction, using interview and/or self-report instruments (e.g., Couples Satisfaction Inventory by Funk and Rogge, Relationship Satisfaction Questionnaire by Burns & Sayers, or the Marital Satisfaction Inventory-Revised by Snyder); provide feedback regarding test results.

sessions.short_term_objective: Identify the strengths and needs of the relationship.
discussion: Have partners identify the strengths and needs of relationship via interviews and questionnaires (e.g., Conflicts and Problem-Solving Scales by Kerig, or the Sexual History Form by LoPiccolo); provide feedback regarding test results.

sessions.short_term_objective: Describe the origination, development, and present state of the relationship.
discussion: Assess the current developmental stage of relationship (e.g., early marriage, parents of young children, long-term marriage); ask partners to list changes they have noted in their relationship as they moved from one stage to the next.

Assess the history of the relationship (appropriate questions might be: “How did the two of you meet?” “What attracted you to each other? “What qualities or characteristics did you find that you liked about your partner?” “How did the two of you decide to get married?” “What have been the highs and lows during dating and your marriage?”).

sessions.short_term_objective: State degree of dissatisfaction with the relationship and own thoughts or actions taken toward dissolving the relationship.
discussion: Assess the steps each partner has taken toward divorce, using the Marital Status Inventory (Weiss & Cerreto) and by interviews with each partner about his/her sense of hope and vision for the future of the relationship.

sessions.short_term_objective: Describe any suspicions regarding the other partner having had an affair.
discussion: Ask each partner to verbalize any suspicions held regarding the other partner having had an affair; assess the presence or suspicion of affairs in the relationship (see chapters on Infidelity and Jealousy in this Planner).

sessions.short_term_objective: Describe the frequency, impact, and function of psychological and/or physical intimate partner violence (IPV).
discussion: Have both couples privately and confidentially complete the Revised Conflict Tactics Scale (CTS2; Straus, Hamby, Boney-McCoy, & Sugarman).

Privately interview each partner about psychological abuse and intimate partner violence (IPV) including (a) antecedents, (b) impact, (c) function, (d) fear, (e) safety issues, (f) extent of psychological coercion or abuse, (g) openness to discuss issues dyadically, and (h) resistance to disclose or discuss violence (see chapters on Psychological Abuse and IPV in this Planner).

sessions.short_term_objective: Process a decision regarding reasons for and against remaining in the relationship.
discussion: Ask partners to discuss the following questions: “Why did we choose to get together?” “How have we developed and matured as individuals and as a unit over the years?” “What are our strengths/accomplishments as a couple?” “What struggles have we survived or surmounted over the years?” “What are the challenges?” “How do our current troubles fit into the entire tapestry of our relationship?”

Provide partners with Baucom, Snyder, & Gordon’s (2008, p. 304) handout detailing “Factors to Consider in Reaching a Decision about Your Relationship” and ask them to discuss each item within the session (i.e., domains of “Evaluating Your Partner,” “Evaluating Your Relationship,” “Evaluating Yourself,” and “Evaluating Your Relationship with the Environment, Including Other People”).

sessions.short_term_objective: List the members of each partner’s extended family who have ended committed relationships, and discuss the impact that this history may have on a decision to divorce.
discussion: Review the extended family history in regard to divorce and have each partner verbalize how this history may be affecting the decision to divorce.

sessions.short_term_objective: Identify any cultural, ethnic, or religious beliefs that may have a bearing on a decision to divorce and verbalize a resolution of such conflicts.
discussion: Ask each partner to identify his/her subcultural identification and its influence on attitude about divorce (e.g., ethnicity, religious identification); facilitate a resolution of conflict between behavior and beliefs.

sessions.short_term_objective: Verbally commit to: (a) relationship therapy, (b) ambivalence therapy, or (c) separation therapy.
discussion: Establish the type of treatment that will be conducted by describing and agreeing on (a) relationship therapy (i.e., the affair will end and the goal will be to salvage the relationship); (b) ambivalence therapy (i.e., the goal will be to clarify the future of the relationship); or (c) separation therapy (i.e., either client is determined to end the relationship, and the goal is to separate under the best possible terms).

Negotiate a “non-collusion contract” with both partners, stipulating that the therapist will not agree to secrecy with either partner, thus establishing the therapist’s role as working for the mutual well-being of the couple.

Clarify for the partners the role of the therapist: to (a) aid the family in making the separation or divorce transition, and (b) help both partners deal with the turbulent emotions experienced during this process. Emphasize that the therapist’s role is to serve the best interests of all family members; however, he/she will not be a mediator or judge.

sessions.short_term_objective: Both partners agree to make no threats nor take any action to hurt themselves or others.
discussion: Ask partners to agree: (a) not to make threats regarding own safety; (b) not to make threats about the safety of others; and (c) to stop discussing difficult topics at home if either partner believes that the discussion is beginning to escalate out-of-control; ask them to avoid deep discussions at home about the future of the relationship during the first phase of treatment.
Assess for suicidality and homicidality by asking each client individually if they have any thoughts, intent, or means to hurt themselves or others.

sessions.short_term_objective: Each partner constructs and implements a self-change plan regarding an anger evoking situation.
discussion: Self-Change Plan ([1] Describe the behavior to be changed; [2] Examine the pros and cons of the current behavior; [3] Set a goal, describing as precisely as possible what is to happen; [4] Create an action plan, pinpointing a specific plan for enacting the goal; [5] Evaluate enacting of plan. Have the partners practice this in session on an area that has evoked anger that each would like to change.
Have both partners agree to use self-change plans to improve their own anger responses instead of managing the other’s behavior.

sessions.short_term_objective: Contract to discuss angry feelings respectfully by balancing concern for the other partner’s feelings with the need to express self.
discussion: Teach both partners the speaker skill of “editing” or “measured truthfulness” (i.e., each balances the need to comment about the other against a concern for the other’s feelings); have them practice this skill on areas of conflict, and contract to use at home.

sessions.short_term_objective: Implement the use of “Pause, Calm, and Think” (i.e., time-out) technique to modulate anger.
discussion: Teach the partners the “Pause, Calm, and Think” technique: Pause the conversation (i.e., letting the other partner know that you want to pause the discussion); Calm down (e.g., focusing on diaphragmatic breathing, counting to 10, focusing on calming self down); Think (e.g., taking responsibility for ways in which you are making the conflict worse; planning ways to respond in a mindful, nonescalating manner instead of automatic, escalating manner; examining thinking by asking self “How true is this thought?” “Is it about just the situation?” “Will it help me get what I want?”).
Practice using “Pause, Calm, and Think” within the session with situations from a real life experience of the couple and then assign at-home implementation.

sessions.short_term_objective: Partners implement the two overarching communication skills of: “Be Clear” and “Be Considerate.”
discussion: Teach the partners the communication skill that emphasizes that interchanges should be (a) clear (i.e., be specific; share thoughts and feelings; pay attention; ask clarifying questions; summarize content and feelings); and (b) considerate (i.e., include positives, show consideration when expressing negatives, let partner know that one is listening even if one disagrees; reserve judgment).
Ask the partners to discuss a low-conflict area of desired change and ask them to rate how well they did being clear.
Ask the partners to discuss a low-conflict area of desired change and ask them to rate how well they did being considerate.

sessions.short_term_objective: Each partner identifies how he/she behaved in ways that improved the relationship, and how he/she behaved in ways that harmed the relationship.
discussion: Ask each partner to turn to the other and express the ways self has (a) contributed to the downfall of the relationship, and (b) in what ways he/she has attempted to make the relationship work.

sessions.short_term_objective: Verbalize empathy for each other while each partner states how divorce will impact personal and social life, immediate and extended family relationship, and spirituality.
discussion: Ask each partner to verbalize the implications of divorce in the following areas: (a) personal, (b) family (including children), (c) religious, and (d) social; have the other partner paraphrase the first person’s statements in each area to increase understanding and empathy between the two partners.

sessions.short_term_objective: Each partner verbalizes a dedication to being sensitive to their children’s thoughts, needs, and feelings during this time of insecurity.
discussion: Sensitize the partners to the upheaval that children face by having them discuss the anticipated effects on their children.

Have partners verbally contract with each other and with the therapist that all decisions in the divorce and separation process will be made with the “best interests of the children” as the paramount concern.

sessions.short_term_objective: Agree on how and what to tell the children regarding the impending divorce; practice the disclosure.
discussion: Using role-playing techniques, have the partners rehearse telling the children together about the divorce; have them explain that (a) they both love the children very much, (b) they plan to divorce, (c) the divorce is not the children’s fault, (d) there is nothing the children can do to get parents back together, and (e) they will both continue to love and see the children.

sessions.short_term_objective: Report on the experience of telling the children regarding the divorce, and agree on what further explanation or support may be necessary.
discussion: Review the experience of parents telling the children of the divorce or separation and probe the needs for further explanation or support; attempt to reach agreement on this issue.

sessions.short_term_objective: Negotiate the terms and conditions of the separation, reaching agreement as to whether and when one partner will move out.
discussion: Facilitate a discussion and decision-making, pending legal advice, regarding whether and when one partner will move out of the house. If an in-house separation is financially necessary, negotiate the terms and conditions.

sessions.short_term_objective: Clarify new boundaries by establishing the new goals of the altered relationship (e.g., to provide the children with healthy home environments), the new prescriptions (e.g., each person supporting the other’s role in the children’s lives), and proscriptions (e.g., no future sexual contact).
discussion: Facilitate an agreement between the partners about new relationship goals (e.g., keeping the welfare of the children primary) and new relationship boundaries such as what forms of contact are acceptable (e.g., planning around children’s activities) as well as what are prohibited (e.g., sexual intimacies).

sessions.short_term_objective: Each partner constructively express his/her emotional pain about the decline of the relationship and verbalize new short- and long-term goals for personal life.
discussion: Using individual sessions as needed, allow each partner to express his/her anger, disappointment, and disapproval over what has happened; balance these expressions of hurt with an elicitation of his/her goals for coping with short-term and long-term situations with the other partner and children.

sessions.short_term_objective: Verbalize an understanding of the differences between litigation, arbitration, and mediation as a means of dissolving the marriage. Agree to one choice.
discussion: Educate partners regarding the three choices available for dissolving the marriage: (a) litigation, which is an adversarial legal process; (b) arbitration, in which a third party, whom each partner typically helps choose, makes decisions regarding property and custody; and (c) mediation, in which the partners come to their own agreement, with the help of a trained mediator.

sessions.short_term_objective: Develop a co-parenting agreement that is in the best interest of the children and deals with the child’s residence, emotional support, financial support, and custody and visitation.
discussion: Facilitate the development of a co-parenting agreement in which the partners pledge that (a) the children’s primary residence will be established in their best interests; (b) neither parent will belittle the other and his/her family members in front of the children; (c) parents will avoid placing the children in loyalty conflicts; and (d) the parents agree regarding terms of financial support for the children.

sessions.short_term_objective: Each partner outlines a plan for how to increase his/her social life and strengthen his/her social and spiritual support system.
discussion: Using individual sessions, assist each partner in developing a varied social network (e.g., asking others to socialize; beginning or increasing involvement in club, community, volunteer, and/or church activities; dating).

sessions.short_term_objective: Cooperate with bringing children to sessions to listen to them express their emotional reactions and needs.
discussion: Conduct parent-child sessions when necessary, to ensure that the children’s emotional needs are being attended to.

sessions.short_term_objective: Accept and follow through on referral to divorce and single-parent support groups.
discussion: Encourage partners to attend local divorce therapy groups and/or self-help groups (e.g., Parents without Partners).

sessions.short_term_objective: Verbalize the effect divorce has had on religious beliefs and practices.
discussion: Assess whether the divorce has affected either partner’s religious and spiritual connections, and assist in problem-solving if he/she has difficulty reestablishing connections (e.g., switching parishes, investigating churches that welcome divorced members).

long_term_goals: Eliminate all types of coercion (physical or verbal) used by one partner to get the other partner to fulfill sexual demands.
Eliminate critical comments of partner’s sexual style.
Eliminate threats to have sex with others.
Eliminate threats to leave the relationship.
Increase general relationship satisfaction.
Increase communication in general, and about sexual matters in particular.
Increase desire for, and enjoyment of, healthy, voluntary sexual activity.
Develop accepting attitude of variability in 'normal' sexual activity.
Develop accepting attitude of changes in sexual activity across a life span.
Evaluate alternatives to current relationship.

sessions.short_term_objective: Agree to a clear ground rule that no physical force will be employed for any sexual interaction.
discussion: Obtain verbal commitment from both partners not to employ physical force for any sexual interaction.
Obtain written commitment from both partners not to employ physical force for any sexual interaction.

sessions.short_term_objective: Agree to a clear ground rule that sexual interactions will only be engaged in if both partners desire to engage in such activity.
discussion: Educate the clients that to have a positive sexual relationship, the sexual activity must be acceptable to both partners.

sessions.short_term_objective: Verbalize an understanding of the fragility of sexual behavior and how it can become less functional with negative feedback or punishment.
discussion: Educate the clients that pressure to have sexual activity usually leads to sexual aversions and/or avoidance and dislike of the partner.

Educate the clients that sexual behavior is one of the most susceptible of all human behaviors to aversive control, and that aversive control of sexual activity can quickly lead to a lack of interest and sexual dysfunction of the partner.

sessions.short_term_objective: Agree to a clear ground rule that there will be no threats to have sex with someone else.
discussion: Obtain a verbal commitment from partners not to threaten to have sex with someone else.

Obtain a commitment from both partners not to have sex with someone else during the course of therapy. This commitment should be obtained individually (i.e., not in the presence of the other partner).

sessions.short_term_objective: Agree to a clear ground rule that there will be no threats to leave partner during the therapy process.
discussion: Obtain a verbal commitment from partners not to threaten to leave the relationship during therapy (an agreement about a particular time span for the therapy should be developed at the beginning of treatment).

sessions.short_term_objective: Agree to a clear ground rule that there will be no physical aggression against the partner for any reason.
discussion: Obtain a verbal commitment from partners not to employ physical force against the other partner for any reason.
Obtain a written commitment from partners not to employ physical force against the other partner for any reason.

sessions.short_term_objective: Describe the nature and extent of any psychological coercion used within the relationship.
discussion: Ask both partners to describe the extent to which psychological coercion is used in the relationship in general.

sessions.short_term_objective: Describe the nature and extent of any physical aggression within the relationship.
discussion: Ask both partners to describe the extent to which physical aggression is used in the relationship in general.

sessions.short_term_objective: State the degree of fear that has resulted from coercion within the relationship, and what effect the fear has had on loving feelings, sexual arousal, and sexual desire.
discussion: Ask both partners to describe any fears they have of their partner and how this fear affects the intimate aspects of the relationship.

sessions.short_term_objective: Verbalize an understanding of the effects on a relationship of control and misuse of power in American society.
discussion: Discuss the role of patriarchy in American society.
Discuss how the controlling partner misuses his/her power.
Educate the clients regarding how controlling behaviors lead to dislike and avoidance of their partner.

sessions.short_term_objective: Describe the history of the sexual relationship and identify where conflicts about sexual matters began to occur.
discussion: Have the clients describe their initial expectations about their sexual life.
Have the clients describe how their expectations about their sexual life changed with the beginning of conflict over intimacy.

sessions.short_term_objective: Verbalize an understanding of the norms of sexual activity and how patterns within the relationship relate to those norms.
discussion: Assist clients in interpreting how the frequency, nature, and satisfaction of their sexual encounters corresponds to that of others of their age in our culture.

sessions.short_term_objective: Describe the positive aspects of the nonsexual portion of the relationship.
discussion: Ask both partners to describe the positive, nonsexual aspects of their current relationship.

sessions.short_term_objective: Describe the positive aspects of the sexual portion of the relationship.
discussion: Ask both partners to describe the positive, sexual aspects of their current relationship.

sessions.short_term_objective: Communicate openly and without criticism, especially about sexual matters.
discussion: Have each partner listen without interrupting while the other partner speaks about a nonsexual matter, and then have him/her validate without interpretation what the other said.
Have each partner communicate about a sexual matter without interruption, and then obtain validation from the other partner.
Provide feedback and interpretation to the partners about their communication styles.

sessions.short_term_objective: Describe the causes for the decline in frequency and enjoyment of sexual encounters.
discussion: Ask the partners to describe the perceived causes for the decline in frequency and enjoyment of sexual activity.

sessions.short_term_objective: Abusive partner describes any physical abuse of self or others in childhood and how these experiences could affect current abuse of his/her partner.
discussion: Explore with the abusive or critical partner whether there has been a history of physical abuse of self or others in childhood family experience.

sessions.short_term_objective: Abused partner describes any physical abuse of self or others in childhood and how these experiences could affect his/her toleration of the current sexual abuse.
discussion: Explore with the abused partner whether there is a history of physical abuse of self or others in a childhood family experience that could be a basis for expecting or tolerating abuse now.

sessions.short_term_objective: Abusive partner describes developmental history of hostile feelings toward the opposite sex that affect current disrespectful treatment of partner.
discussion: Explore with the abusive partner whether there is a history of anger toward the opposite sex that has roots in unresolved childhood experiences.

sessions.short_term_objective: Abusive partner verbalizes feelings of low self-esteem and lack of trust in others that feeds the abusive behavior toward his/her partner.
discussion: Probe the degree to which the abuser trusts that sexual activity would be freely and happily engaged in by the other partner if coercion was not present (that is, does he/she feel lovable and able to trust anyone?).

sessions.short_term_objective: Verbalize understanding that sexual coercion or degrading criticism changes sexual behaviors into acts of domination and/or submission.
discussion: Confront sexual coercion or belittling criticism as a means of domination that degrades the other partner from a role as lover to that of a victim.

sessions.short_term_objective: Describe any traumatic sexual experiences experienced outside of the relationship.
discussion: Have each client identify any traumatic sexual experiences that he/she encountered with anyone.

sessions.short_term_objective: Agree to terminate any sexual activity that triggers negative emotions related to earlier sexual trauma.
discussion: Advise the partners to cease any sexual activity that triggers memories of traumatic events.

sessions.short_term_objective: Engage in sensate focus with the partners.
discussion: Instruct each client in use of sensate focus technique to teach their partner how to touch self.

sessions.short_term_objective: Discuss sensate focus activities with the partners in therapy sessions, and change sexual stimulation activities based on feedback from the other partner.
discussion: Obtain feedback from the clients about the sensate focus exercises, and assist in minimizing any behaviors that affect either partner negatively.

sessions.short_term_objective: Assess alternatives to relationship, and receive referrals for safely escaping from abuse.
discussion: In an individual session, discuss with the sexually abused client the alternatives to the current relationship.
In a confidential individual session, help the sexually abused client evaluate the alternatives to the current relationship.
If necessary, refer the sexually abused client to an agency for battered women and/or to a shelter.

long_term_goals: Increase desire for, and enjoyment of, sexual activity.
Increase and maintain physiological arousal during sexual interactions.
Reach orgasm on a regular basis.
Eliminate pain associated with any aspect of the sexual interaction; eliminate spasms that prevent intromission.
Increase communication and general relationship satisfaction.
Increase both partners’ self-esteem.
Develop accepting attitude toward variability in “normal” sexual activity.
Develop accepting attitudes toward changes in the intensity and frequency of sexual activity across a life span.

sessions.short_term_objective: Describe the history of the sexual relationship and identify when conflicts about sexual matters began to occur.
discussion: Assess the frequency of sexual interactions across the history of the partners’ relationship.
Assess the partners’ enjoyment of sexual interactions across the history of their relationship.

Ask the partners to describe the perceived causes of decline in sexual activity and enjoyment thereof (e.g., sexual coercion, sexual aggression, infidelity, relationship decline, childhood experiences, etc.); or assign 'Factors Influencing Negative Sexual Attitudes' in the Adult Psychotherapy Homework Planner, 2nd ed. by Jongsma.

sessions.short_term_objective: Identify the positive aspects of the nonsexual portion of the relationship.
discussion: Ask the partners to describe the positive nonsexual aspects of the beginning of their relationship.
Ask the partners to describe the positive nonsexual aspects of their current relationship.

sessions.short_term_objective: Describe the positive aspects of the sexual relationship.
discussion: Ask the partners to describe the positive sexual aspects of the beginning of their relationship.
Ask the partners to describe the positive sexual aspects of their current relationship.

sessions.short_term_objective: Communicate openly and without criticism, especially about sexual matters.
discussion: Ask the partners to communicate with each other about a nonsexual matter; listener should allow partner to speak without interruption and, to demonstrate understanding, should paraphrase the speaker’s intent.

Ask the partners to communicate with each other about a sexual matter; listener should allow partner to speak without interruption and, to demonstrate understanding, should paraphrase the speaker’s intent.
Provide feedback and interpretation to the partners about their communication styles.

sessions.short_term_objective: Identify sexual expectations in the relationship and how they have changed across time.
discussion: Ask each partner to describe initial expectations about his/her sexual life.
Have each partner describe how expectations about his/her sexual life have changed.
Assist the partners in interpreting how the frequency and satisfaction of their sexual encounters correspond to that of other people their age.

sessions.short_term_objective: Describe any past traumatic experience that now may be impacting sexual interactions.
discussion: Have each partner discuss any past traumatic sexual experiences.

Probe about thoughts during sexual activities and ascertain whether the traumatic sexual encounter triggers negative emotions during sexual overtures or activity; if found, resolve past traumas that impact current sexual pleasure.

sessions.short_term_objective: Identify any religious beliefs or training that may be interfering with experiencing pleasure from sexual activity.
discussion: Examine whether religious beliefs or training interferes with engaging in sexual activity desired by either partner; if interferences exist, attempt to neutralize current impact, or define acceptable sexual practices.

sessions.short_term_objective: Cease any activity that triggers memories of past traumatic experiences until the feelings related to that activity can be resolved.
discussion: Recommend that the partners temporarily cease any sexual activity that triggers memories of traumatic events until traumatic memories are properly resolved (for treatment ideas for sexual abuse see The Sexual Abuse Victim and Sexual Offender Treatment Planner by Budrionis and Jongsma).

sessions.short_term_objective: Discuss the development of sexual attitudes in the family-of-origin.
discussion: Assist the partners in identifying family-of-origin experiences that enhance and those that deter one or both partners from currently experiencing sexual pleasure.

sessions.short_term_objective: Identify and resolve, if possible, any physical disorder or medication that is inhibiting sexual desire.
discussion: Assess the role of any known or possible existing physical condition that could interfere with sexual functioning (e.g., diabetes, substance abuse, depression, anxiety disorders).

Assess the role of any medication that could interfere with sexual functioning (e.g., antihypertensive medication, antidepressant medication); after obtaining a release, discuss this issue with the partner’s prescribing physician to consider alternative medications.

sessions.short_term_objective: Verbalize feelings regarding body image and how it relates to sexual functioning.
discussion: Explore whether the decrease in the frequency and range of sexual activities is related to a decline in body image (e.g., increased body weight, lack of muscle tone, or the residual effects of surgery).

sessions.short_term_objective: Verbalize an improved body image due to increased exercise, improved dress, and/or a more healthy diet.
discussion: Encourage a positive change in attitude regarding the partner’s body image (or assign 'Study Your Body: Clothed and Unclothed' in the Adult Psychotherapy Homework Planner, 2nd ed. by Jongsma).
Assign a change in exercise, dress, and/or diet to enhance partner’s body image.

sessions.short_term_objective: Identify causes and remedies for low self-esteem within the relationship.
discussion: Assess the role of self-esteem in sexual functioning, and identify the factors in the relationship that lead to positive and negative feelings.

sessions.short_term_objective: Identify whether a perceived or real emotionally intimate or sexual relationship with another partner creates continuing resentment and/or jealousy.
discussion: Probe hurt or angry feelings that relate to perceived or actual extramarital affairs by one of the partners, and make certain that such relationships have stopped.

sessions.short_term_objective: Verbalize whether any same-sex activity and/or fantasy impedes sexual functioning with the partner, openly acknowledging plans for future direction of sexual interest.
discussion: Assess (in individual sessions) whether there are any same-sex desires, attractions, or behaviors on the part of either partner that interfere with heterosexual functioning.
If there are same-sex activities or fantasies that interfere with the couple’s sexual relationship, explore the sexual identity issue and its implication for the future of heterosexual relationships.

sessions.short_term_objective: Report an increase in sexual thoughts and/or fantasy when not engaged in sexual activity with the partner.
discussion: Request that the partners indulge in sexual fantasies while not engaged with the partner sexually that increase sexual desire toward their partner.

sessions.short_term_objective: Read books and/or watch educational videos on sexual functioning and sexuality.
discussion: Request that the partners read material on sexual fantasies (e.g., My Secret Garden by Friday, Women on Top by Friday, Becoming Orgasmic: A Sexual Growth Program for Women by Heiman & LoPiccolo).

If religious views permit, the partners, especially females, can be encouraged to purchase educational videos of sexual activities to teach enhancement of fantasy, masturbation, and a variety of heterosexual sexual behaviors (e.g., Self-Loving by Dodson, and the Better Sex Video Series: Vols. 1–3 by the Sinclair Institute).

Suggest that the partners read books on sexual behavior and sexual functioning (e.g., Sex for Dummies by Westheimer, The New Male Sexuality by Zilbergeld, The New Joy of Sex by Comfort, The Gift of Sex by Penner & Penner, and When a Woman’s Body Says No to Sex by Valins).

sessions.short_term_objective: Engage in sensate focus activity alone and with partner.
discussion: Instruct both partners in the use of sensate focus to learn how to touch each other.

sessions.short_term_objective: Discuss sensate focus activities with the partners in therapy sessions, and change sexual stimulation activities based on feedback from the other partner.
discussion: Obtain feedback from the partners about the sensate focus exercises, and assist in minimizing any behaviors that affect either partner negatively (or assign 'Journaling the Response to Nondemand Sexual Pleasuring [Sensate Focus]' in the Adult Psychotherapy Homework Planner, 2nd ed. by Jongsma).

sessions.short_term_objective: Report progress on graduated self-controlled vaginal penetration with the partner.
discussion: Assign the partner body exploration and awareness exercises that reduce inhibition and desensitize him/her to sexual aversion.
Direct the partner’s use of masturbation and/or vaginal dilator devices to reinforce relaxation and success surrounding vaginal penetration.
Direct the partners in sexual exercises that allow for partner-controlled level of genital stimulation and gradually increased vaginal penetration.

long_term_goals: Both partners form attachment bond with the infant.
Partners agree on and participate in infant care.
Each partner notices and verbalizes appreciation for infant care and support.
Partners manage stress without taking it out on the infant or partner.
Partners discuss and agree on strategy for balancing work, household, relationship, family, and community responsibilities.
Partners discuss feelings about sex/rejection and eventually reestablish sexual relationship.

sessions.short_term_objective: Play with the baby and support the other parent doing so.
discussion: Ask each parent to generate times for (a) fun activities to do with the baby (e.g., time of day when he/she is available and the baby is quiet and alert); and (b) bonding interaction (e.g., showing affection, carrying and holding the baby, making eye contact and talking to the baby).
Ask parents to share plans with each other.
Ask each partner to generate ways in which he/she could support the other’s plans for activity with the baby.

sessions.short_term_objective: Each partner develops competence in managing the infant’s sleeping, feeding, and crying and supports other parent doing so.
discussion: Have both parents list (a) how they’ve been successfully managing the infant’s sleeping, feeding, and crying; (b) areas in which they’ve been challenged or are having difficulty; and (c) how they’re supporting the other’s efforts.
Ask parents to describe conflicts over how they’re responding to infant’s sleeping, feeding, and crying.

Ask both parents to read material on a baby’s first year of development (e.g., Your Baby's First Year by the American Academy of Pediatrics, or What to Expect the First Year by Murkoff, Mazel, Eisenberg, & Hathaway).

sessions.short_term_objective: Each partner constructs and implements a self-change plan that would help in the transition to parenthood.
discussion: Teach the partners the five steps of a Self-Change Plan: (1) Describe the behavior to be changed; (2) Examine the pros and cons of the current behavior; (3) Set a goal, describing as precisely as possible what is to happen; (4) Create an Action Plan, pinpointing a specific plan for enacting the goal; and (5) Evaluate enacting of the plan. Have the partners practice this in session on an area which has evoked anger that each would like to change.
Ask both partners to agree to use self-change plans to improve their own transition behaviors instead of managing the other’s behavior.

sessions.short_term_objective: Partners implement the two overarching communication skills of: “Be Clear” and “Be Considerate.”
discussion: Teach the partners the communication skill that emphasizes that interchanges should be: (a) clear (i.e., be specific, share thoughts and feelings, pay attention, ask clarifying questions, summarize content and feelings); and (b) considerate (i.e., include positives, show consideration when expressing negatives, let the partner know that one is listening even if one disagrees, reserve judgment).
Ask the partners to discuss a low-conflict area of desired change and ask them to rate how well they did being clear.
Ask the partners to discuss a low-conflict area of desired change and ask them to rate how well they did being considerate.

sessions.short_term_objective: Practice defining problems in specific, nonblaming terms.
discussion: Have the partners take turns pinpointing problems (that is, making requests for change that are specific, observable, and ask for increases rather than decreases in the other partner’s behavior).
